reviewText: By pure chance, I happened to catch 'Finding Neverland' sneak peek.  I highly recommend it.  It is such a 'pretty' movie.  The Neverland sets for J.M. Barrie's play are enchanting and completly catch you up in the magic of it all.  The acting is wonderful, a definate audience connection.  Johnny Depp is brillent and Kate Winslet adds such a soft strength.  The children were perfect and the whole film thourughly inspirational.

I was lucky enough to catch this at the sneak preview and I am so glad I did.  Now when I write a review for a movie starring Johnny Depp I can hardly say my opinion is unbiased, as I do own 10 movies he's starred in and two posters adorn my walls, but I believe non-fans of him will enjoy the magic of "Finding Neverland."

The story of J.M. Barrie and his inspiration for the famous play "Peter Pan" will pull on your heartstrings and make you see the magic of being a child and the power of imagination. During a chance meeting at a park after a disastrous play the night before, Barrie (Johnny Depp) meets the widow Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet) and her four boys.  They become quick friends because of Barrie's childlike personality and antics.

The whole movie is very well-casted with both the adults and the children.  Depp gives his usual knockout performance that makes you believe that he truly is J.M. Barrie.  Kate Winslet also shines at Sylvia Davies and plays her role with elegance and truly fits her character.  Still, one of the best stars in the movie is Freddie Highmore who plays Peter, Barrie's inspiration for the boy who never wants to grow up.  He displays his emotions so well and makes a real connection with the audience.  Castmates, Depp and Winslet, were very impressed with his acting talent, and Depp even got Highmore the role of Charlie in the upcoming movie "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory." Highmore almost steals the show, but Depp and Winslet's performances shine through with their onscreen chemistry and a lot of heart.  The supporting cast featuring Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman is not to be ignored, as they both give great performances as their characters.  Julie Christie plays a perfect sort of `villian' in the film as Sylvia's mother who wants Barrie out of her son's lives and Dustin Hoffman brings comedic light wherever he shows up in the movie as Barrie's play producer.

The story is simplistic, but is told with a lot of charm and a great mixture of humor and emotions that will make you laugh and then, moments later, get teary-eyed.  `Finding Neverland' is a magical ride with great acting and can take you away to your own Neverland.

This is truly a great film that has earned the Oscar as the best film of the year as far as I'm concerned. Everything here from the acting to the direction is perfect. I have seen "Ray" also, but I think Johnny Depp will give Jamie Foxx a run for his money come the next Academy Awards. Depp's new accent (it changes in every film) and acting are perfect as expected. Kate Winslet and her four boys make up the strong supporting cast and Dustin Hoffman steals a couple of scenes with some great lines. This movie may be a little slow for some people, but magic is in this film for those who come with a little patience...oh, and a box of kleenex for the ladies.

A strong affectionate portrait of the man who gave us Peter Pan

,that had most of the audience I saw it with in tears. Great acting by the four child actors who portray the inspiration for Barrie's adventure. A movie for all of us who don't want to grow up.

Out of all the movies that I've seen this year, (which has been many), I thought this movie,"Finding Neverland", was the best. It is about how the writer of Peter Pan came up with his ideas. I don't want to give away the movie but here is a brief overview: The movie starts out with one of James M. Barrie's unsuccessful plays, but soon moves on to James meeting four young children and their mother in a park. The children are fatherless. Though he is already married, James becomes attached to the familly and spends most of his time playing with the kids. The games that he plays with the children soon inspire his greatest work, "Peter Pan". This is a pretty short description of the movie and doesn't explain much at all but to any one who reads this, I encourage you to see this movie, which to me, again, is the best of the year.

By the time Johnny Depp receives his due, it will be long overdue. There are many elements of beauty in this film; Depp's performance as J.M. Barrie, the author of "Peter Pan", is one of the most moving.

In thinking back over some of my favorite of his performances: "What's Eating Gilbert Grape?", "Edward Scissorhands", "Chocolat", "Pirates of the Caribbean", among others, I was trying to distill the reason why there is not a "Johnny Depp"-identifiable role-- a typecast part which we all recognize Depp must play. And yet, when Johnny Depp plays a role, it becomes impossible to imagine it being played by anyone else. Depp seems to be a genuine romantic in his real life, and that may be part of the something special he brings to the souls of the characters he plays. They are "romantic" in the classical sense. Somehow he leaves this jaded, too-hip, too-wise-and-world-weary world behind in bringing to life characters who are rarely motivated by cynicism, but who are open and susceptible to the splendid draughts and drags of emotionally large and tumultuous or tiny and subtle events. His eyes are magic. He is a spellbinder.

The cynical may well be uncomfortable with this movie. It is, after all, about the power of "believing"--- and pretending---, about a playwright who did not want to grow up, but who recognized to the fraction of an instant when the dividing line between childhood and adulthood had been crossed. On the other hand, if you have the genius, as did J.M. Barrie in this story, to scatter a child's view throughout the theater of your perception, then the pure romance of the biographical story ("inspired by true events", but not necessarily true events) behind the story of the creation of "Peter Pan" is wonderfully transporting.

Evocative music, unabashedly old-fashioned and romantic, was my first clue that I had come to the theater ill-equipped. I was going to need Kleenex, and I had none. The characters are played by exceptionally beautiful people: Kate Winslet is lovely and likeable as Mrs. Llewelyn-Davies, widowed mother of the boys who became the inspiration for Barrie's most famous play; the luminous Julie Christie as Mrs. du Maurier, Mrs. Llewelyn's mother, is almost our hero's antagonist in opposing Barrie's involvement with her daughter and grandchildren, and yet her motives are understandable; the Llewelyn-Davies children, especially Peter, played by Freddie Highmore, are people we would like to meet and have as friends almost from the instant they appear on screen. Even Barrie's poor wife (Radha Mitchell), supportive when his previous play flops, then neglected in favor of his muse and inspiration for his greatly successful play "Peter Pan", is a sympathetic figure in spite of her conflict with her charming husband.  When Dustin Hoffman becomes a mere foil and a footnote as the play's producer, one clearly has an abundance of riches.

The cinematographer and set designer do a lovely job of marrying the fantasy and the reality: the film looks beautiful. Highlighted details like the early electric lightbulbs and the period automobiles underscore the changing of an age and the "toys-for-adults" aspect of nascent industrial technology. The costuming is also a visual treat.

Without being too overtly didactic, the movie both illustrates inspiration and inspires. If you aspire to be a writer, or just to reclaim a little innocence, this would be one to own on DVD when it comes out. But don't deny yourself the marvelous pleasure of seeing it now, and rooting for it to be remembered at Oscar time. Take Kleenex.

Such a beautiful family movie, "Finding Neverland", which is based on the story of the creator of the play of Peter Pan for the twentieth-century stage, James M. Barrie (Johnny Depp). Being in a marriage which lacks the fire of any imagination that he is filled to overflowing with, he meets a lovely woman, Sylvia (Kate Winslet) who has four inquisitive little boys who adore Barrie and entertain him too. They inspire his interest with their imaginative plays prodding Barrie's limitations further. Julie Christie (Mrs. Emma du Maurier) makes a believable appearance as Sylvia's mother adding a freshness to this film of happiness and family love along with a great supply of laughter within the story of the happenings with the boys. However, this also includes a true to life occurrence that doesn't make one overjoyed but services the story as it is loosely based on truth. With a great story that I think is timeless and with a rating for the whole family, this film is one that is safe to pull out to entertain your family right down to showing parts of the play that Barrie debuts on stage. Awe-inspiring for the boys, but also for the viewer, this movie is a keeper and was cast perfectly in every role. I dare you not to fall for those little boys as I sure did and still do.
absolutely wonderful film, do not listen to anyone who says it is boring.

One of my favorite movies ever! Amazing backstory on how the show Peter Pan came to life. The acting is superb and the soundtrack is phenomenal. This movie tugs at the heartstrings and gives you a new appreciation for the power of imagination.

Enjoyable when it came out and enjoyable still! I really liked all the actors, and everyone seemed very realistic to me. Dustin Hoffman's small role was hilarious. Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet are always amazing. Everyone did a fantastic job, and I loved this movie. As for characters, real life people though they may be, I didn't like his wife, at least not how she was depicted in this film. She was not only selfish, but extra terrible to try and act like her actions were justified! He wasn't perfect, but that does not warrant another to do something wrong. Anyway, I think if you love Peter Pan, or simply would like to know a small history about the writer/playwright behind the story, then I recommend this one wholeheartedly.

From time to time a movie comes about with a foundation of a quality human story presented in such a subtle, gentle manner that it achieves a balance of innocence and magic as it takes us to a place far beyond the limitations the characters are experiencing. I saw this movie years ago, I just watched it again, what a pleasure it was to be reminded of how charming and heartwarming of a story it is, how lovely it unfolds and how grateful it feels when it is complete. A precursor to Peter Pan with a spirit equally as entrancing as Pan is imaginative and both equally uplifting, it is a definite solid choice, if not a great call for an evening you want to take you to a appreciative, life affirming place.

The movie tells the story behind the idea and creative birth pangs of Neverland as it was developed into the hit play "Peter Pan." I was expecting a light-hearted movie, but this movie involves emotional heartache, betrayal and struggle; as well as discovering love, finding inspiration, and never giving up. As an actor, Johnny Depp knows how to portray his character to the fullest, and he did it again in this movie. Not a fast-paced movie, yet it was a good movie that kept my interest right to the end!

Their outcome was pretty tragic and of course not brought up in the Hollywood version.  They can't handle the truth, or more to the point would anyone see a movie that exposed a famous playwright  and his "love" of the boys.

The movie brought the viewer into 1903 from the very beginning. Johnny Depp was captivating with his very believable portrayal of J.M. Barrie and the rest of the cast was superb in their roles. The most wonderful aspect of the film was the interaction between Depp and the boys, especially Young Peter. There was a connection between the "Adult Boy" (Depp) and the younger boys that kept the movie flowing down the stream of Imagination, culminating in the Play that had its home in Neverland . The Director did a great job of blending the Play of Peter Pan with the Movie and the choice of the Theater was well done, bringing the viewer elbow to elbow with the Audience and enjoying the magic of the Play's premier. There were enough scenes of the Society of the Times to perfectly balance the  moments when Barrie chose to "play" with the Boys. The scenes with Depp and Kate Winslet added the serious tone that helped to separate the Grown-up Barrie from the Young Boy Barrie and keep the viewer anchored in the real world of 1903 London. Anyone collecting films starring Johnny Depp should certainly get their hands on this one!

Although an older movie now, Finding Neverland has a timeless story line. Based on the life of the creator of Peter Pan, J.M. Barrie, it narrates how the famous playwrite's story of Peter Pan came to be. In this movie, which is not entirely true to the actual events, J.M. Barrie, who is played by Johnny Dep, has just written and produced a play that is flop and is desperately trying to come up with ideas for a new and better play.

While walking his dog in Kensington Gardens he happens to meet Sylvia and her four sons, one of whom is named Peter. He becomes very active in the lives of the widowed Sylvia, played by Kate Winslet, and her sons. He finds the imaginations of the four boys to be fascinating and helps to foster their imagination by engaging them in games and stories, all the time keeping a ledger of the boy's lives and his daily encounters with them. As the days and weeks pass, he begins to develope a story based on his encounters with the young boys and the fantasy world he has helped them to create.

Along the way he has to deal with his jealous wife and Sylvia's mother, who objects to Barrie's constant envolvement with her daughter and grandsons. Also, his friends advise him not to get involved with the Llewelyn Davis family because of the appearance it portrays to the community. But despite all this he becomes a kind of father figure to the boys and begins to write his new play based on the idea that the boys never wish to grow up and therefore bring to life a fantasy land that Barrie names Never Land.

As the story progresses, it becomes evident that Barrie's new play seems to be total lunacy to his friends and stage colleagues but he believes that his new play will be a suscess. On opening night he "plants" children throughout the theater and at first the sophisticated adults don't seem to understand his new play. But as the children watch the play they begin to giggle and laugh and the adults then begin to understand the meaning of the play and then they too find the humor and magic in the play. The play becomes a sensation almost overnight!

I suppose the enjoyment one takes from this film may depend a great deal on how much of a fan you are of the creative inspirations of J. M. Barrie, particularly his stage play that became the eventual Disney Film, Peter Pan. His life was one of success as a writer but personal tragedies, and the movie makes a sympathetic and heartfelt examination of his life in early 20th Century London. Performances by Depp and Winslet were fine, though I felt Depp's British accent wandered into Ireland at times.

Johnny Depp takes us by the hand and in the gentlest most reassuring way leads into the heart, soul and mind of an artist. How easy is for the world to judge. How frightened we still are of all we don't understand. The very nature of innocence is suspect because innocence belongs exclusively to the innocent. Every time the world claims to protect it, tends to destroy it. "Finding Nerverland" is filled with moments of enlightenment. Moving and powerful moments but none more so than Julie Christie's face as she applauds, converted to the fantasy transported into her daughter's house. The moment and the enlightenment are short lived, but, somehow, remains in my mind as a glimmer of hope. If for a moment she accepts the mystery of it all, maybe we all could. Johnny Depp is the best American actor of his generation, period. Kate Winslet is a stunning rarity among her contemporaries. She doesn't look like anybody else and the camera catches every tiny little thought that crosses her marvelous face.

This movie has an unexpected death of the mother,Kate Winslet,r of four boys so the grief is lightened when she goes to lighthearted Neverland,a place that Sir James Barrie played by Johnny Depp,wrote in his Peter Pan strory about the" lo,st boys. This famous story incorporated Mr. Barrie's observance of the Davies Family during the time he spent with them during the time before Syliva Luellen Davies died of lung cancer and the learning adventures they had together. Mr. Barrie wife left him as a result of daily time spent with the boys" & their mother,the so called muse. Julie Christy played the part of the boys grandmother & played an important part of needing to help the Davies family survive thru the confusing time of wanting to help her daughter's family after the recent death of the boy's father. This movie filled in many unknown facts about the famous story of Peter Pan!

Finding Neverland is a semi-biographical film about the story focuses on Scottish writer J. M. Barrie, his platonic relationship with Sylvia Llewelyn Davies, and his close friendship with her sons, who inspire the classic play Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up. It stars Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet together with Radha Mitchell,Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman. The screenplay by David Magee is based on the play The Man Who Was Peter Pan by Allan Knee. It was directed by Marc Forster.

Following the dismal reception of his latest play, Little Mary, Barrie meets the widowed Sylvia and her four young sons in Kensington Gardens, and a strong friendship develops between them. He proves to be a great playmate and surrogate father figure for the boys, and their imaginative antics give him ideas which he incorporates into a play about boys who do not want to grow up, especially one named after troubled young Peter Llewelyn Davies. His wife Mary, who eventually divorces him, and Sylvia's mother Emma du Maurier, object to the amount of time Barrie spends with the Llewelyn Davies family. Emma also seeks to control her daughter and grandsons, especially as Sylvia becomes increasingly weak from an unidentified illness. Producer Charles Frohman skeptically agrees to mount Peter Pan despite his belief it holds no appeal for upper-class theatergoers. Barrie peppers the opening night audience with children from a nearby orphanage, and the adults present react to their infectious delight with an appreciation of their own. The play proves to be a huge success. Because Sylvia is too ill to attend the production, Barrie arranges to have an abridged production of it performed in her home. She dies shortly afterward, and Barrie finds that her will is to have him and her mother to look after the boys; an arrangement agreeable to both.

Finding Neverland is not exactly the way it happened, but this is a movie with a higher truth, one we need to believe in. And you will believe. You will. Like Big Fish and The Neverending Story, this is a film that reminds us that life, colored by our perceptions, is what we make it; all we have to do is believe. It won't pass muster for those looking for historical and Johnny Depp gives a graceful performance as Peter Pan creator J.M. Barrie.

I fail to understand why it has been so popular with both critics and public. I found this movie quite flat. I don't mind a movie which does not stick perfectly with fact, or even a movie who just ignore half of the facts or questions raised by the topic. It is ok so long they entertain me and "capture the spirit" of the story. I found this movie wanting on all of the above.
It never really brings you to Neverland, you never frankly bond with the characters, the question of the relationship between the characters is dodged to focus on other subject but I think it was a mistake that deprived the story and its characters of contrast and depth and genuine humanity.

That said, it's not an awful movie, just not a very good one either.

I enjoyed this movie because I had always been curious about the life of J. M. Barrie and what could have motivated him to write a classic children's story that appeals to readers/audiences even now.  Peter Pan is one of my favorite child characters in fiction, perhaps second only to Alice.  This movie, in which Barrie is played so well by Johnny Depp, I think captures the love Barrie must  have felt for the Davies boys and probably their mother.  We can't know for certain what J. M. Barrie's inspiration for writing "Peter Pan" was but we can get on board with the idea that it arose from love and that is what this movie is all about.  Recommended.

Finding Neverland is an uplifting movie about J. M. Barrie, the author who was the creator of Peter Pan.  The story is based on real events.

The movie stars Johnny Depp (without his pirate costume) who plays Barrie, Dusty Hoffman, Kate Winslet, and Radha Mitchell.  The movie takes place in London and opens with Barrie peering behind the curtain to see the audiences reaction to his play on opening night.  Hes disappointed to discover it isn't well received.

Barrie goes to a Kensington Garden to write.  While there he meets four young boys, including one named Peter, and their mother.  Barrie and the family soon become friends and get together regularly.  While Barrie plays make-believe games with the boys such as pirates or cowboys and Indians, he is able to visualize the fantasy world they're creating.

The boys father died of cancer recently and soon their mother becomes ill.  Barrie becomes a father figure to the boy and of financial support.

Meanwhile, Barries marriage is falling apart as he spends more and more time with this new family and less time with his already estranged wife.

The story shows how Barries friendship with the boys inspired him to write a play about a group of boys who don't want to grow up and led to the creation of Peter Pan.  But the story isn't just about the creation of a beloved, timeless story.  Its about young boys dealing with the loss of their father and a sick mother.

In conclusion, the movie captures the magic of Peter Pan and we see that world through the authors mind full of fairies, pirates, and children who can fly.
Old and young alike will enjoy this delightful, creative movie.

This was a modified telling of the true story of Sir James Matthew Barrie, author of Peter Pan and other works.  The historical facts were changed ad rearranged but the spirit of the story was true.  I found it fascinating that a man who should have grown up very flawed, considering his childhood being raised by a severely depressed mother, turned out so well.  He was very child-like in his approach to life but went on to create lasting stories and left a great legacy in an adult world.  The players in this movie were all first rate and the story engaging.  The message - If we should only "believe".  Great for children who want to believe in fairies and a fairy world and adults who seek and find Something or Someone greater to believe in.

A competent cast and a fine characterization (complete with convincing accent) by Johnny Depp make this an interesting  movie for those fond of period pieces or just interested in the background story of how 'Peter Pan' was born.  Being a Anglophile would also help as well.

I rated four stars instead of five because I think that's a very specialized audience - romance and action lovers, for example, will not find anything to hold their attention here.  Additionally, the film becomes a bit too surreal in a few spots and that seems to throw the dramatic timing off.

Trivia: If you look closely you will see some familiar faces from 'Pirates of the Caribbean' and 'Hunger Games'.

The movie is quite enjoyable--though surprisingly melancholy for a film framed around fantasy and delight.  My primary fault is based on how loosely it plays with the facts.  Viewers who watch this thinking it is the real story of J. M. Barrie and the writing of the Peter Pan play and novels will be sorely misinformed.  It would be rather like watching an Oliver Stone film and thinking you know the real history.

For someone who is looking for a movie with an interesting plot line that is effectively presented--that is, worthwhile entertainment--this film qualifies.

This movie allows all of us to return to the childhood mindset of wonder and awe.  The costumes and settings are elegant and rich.  This is some of the best work Julie Christie and Johnny Depp have done.  Their characters are deep and moving.  I love the one-liners from Dustin Hoffman, delivered with just the right timing.  Kate Winslett is quite believable in her character as a widow with children.  She evokes a protective response in the viewer.  Finding Neverland is filled with emotion and hope.  It is an inspiring movie for all artists.

"Finding Neverland" is a great concept for a movie, attempting to show how the author of "Peter Pan" discovered the wonder of life as he wrote his beloved tale.  However, I found both lead actors to be too heavy and unconvincing in the joy they were supposed to exude.  It was nonetheless a good movie, but left me wishing for more --- more charm, more spirit, more heart-felt delight.  In contrast, "Miss Potter", a movie similar in theme (unfolding the life behind Harriet Potter, the author of "Peter Rabbit"), succeeded remarkably in winning the heart. "Finding Neverland" was scripted well, but unfortunately, falls short of the magic it is all about.

FINDING NEVERLAND is a short biopic about author J.M. Barrie and how he came to write the play PETER PAN, which has gone on to become one of the most famous works of theatre and children's literature ever. The movie opens as Barrie watches his latest play being performed, displaying his anxiety. The play is a flop. From there the movie goes on to show Barrie's first meeting of the Llewelyn-Davies family, how he became friends with the family, the estrangement and eventual divorce from his wife, and how the Llewelyn Davies children inspired the creation of PETER PAN.

Johnny Depp portrays Barrie. As is usually the case, Depp is in excellent form and is well deserving of the Oscar nomination he received. Kate Winslet plays the widowed and dying Sylvia Llewelyn Davies. Winslet has had a career of hits and misses. Her performance in FINDING NEVERLAND is one of her better performances, displaying a full range of her skills, rather than just typecasting her as a beautiful young romantic or as a naked crazy woman (or as the case in TITANIC the beautiful young naked woman). Dustin Hoffman has a supporting role in the film as does Ian Hart. However, it is the performance of Freddie Highmore as Peter Llewelyn Davies that is most outstanding. Highmore's performance is remarkable and is just as extraordinary as Haley Joel Osment in THE SIXTH SENSE. It's a shame that Highmore didn't gain an Oscar nomination (though he did become friends with Depp-who he shares a birthday with-and Depp had him cast as Charlie Bucket in the upcoming Tim Burton version of CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY).

FINDING NEVERLAND is a touching film that doesn't degrade itself to schmaltz. The film plays with certain details of Barrie's life to make the movie more dramatic (for example, Arthur Llewelyn Davies was still alive when Barrie first met his family; there were five sons instead of four). Still, it does a great job at showing how Barrie's experiences with the Llewelyn Davies inspired the creation of Peter Pan. Most of the time the film also shies away from the mushy sentimentality that so many other films of similar type succumb to. FINDING NEVERLAND shows the good along with some of the bad and that even though a person may "need to go on pretending. Until the end.", sometimes we can only dream on a budget.

This movie should have been called "Finding Fantasyland," since its only resemblance to the true story of J.M. Barrie and his relationship with the Llewellyn Davies children is their names. It's hard to understand what the makers of this movie were trying to accomplish. It begins with Arthur Llewellyn Davies already dead, when in actual fact Barrie had been a friend of the family for over six years when Arthur died, entering the scene before Michael and Nico had been born. By the time Arthur died he was a firm fixture in their lives ("Uncle Jimmy"), and was able to offer financial assistance to the family immediately upon his death. With such a wealth of information available about Barrie's and the Llewellyn Davies' lives (one such source can be found at jmbarrie.co.uk, the collected documentation in letters and notes written by Barrie and the Llewellyn Davies' themselves, as well as the outstanding book "J. M. Barrie and the Lost Boys: The Real Story Behind Peter Pan," by Andrew Birkin), it is difficult to understand why the makers of this movie felt it necessary to fudge the facts. The whole thing seems to be focused on the special relationship between Barrie and Peter, when in fact it was George who had the special relationship with Barrie. The entire movie seems to be conjecture and fantasy. If you are really interested in learning more about the man behind Peter Pan, I highly recommend that you skip this movie and go straight to the Birkin book. And if you really want a "movie," then I recommend the docudrama, "The Lost Boys," a BBC film starring Ian Holm based upon the Andrew Birkin book. The latter is actually rooted in fact.

The story of the man who wrote Peter Pan, author James M. Barrie, Finding Neverland features another phenomenal performance by Johnny Depp. As the story begins, playwright Barrie (Depp) has staged a recent flop and his producer (Dustin Hoffman) is getting impatient.

Finding Neverland presents a fictional account of Barrie's creative life and the inspirations that helped bring Peter Pan to the stage. Barrie meets the four Davies boys and their mother, Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet) in London's Kensington Gardens. Captured by their boyish imagination and touched by the recent loss of their father, he begins to tell them stories and is eventually inspired to write a play about a boy who stays young forever. The Davies boys show him Neverland, and he shows it to the world.

Depp, with his own boyish looks and childhood spirit, is perfect as Barrie. Freddie Highmore, who portrays the young Peter Davies, gives a remarkable toughness and sensitivity to his first movie role.
Great movie!  Peter Pan has always been one of my favorites and this tells the story of the author of Peter Pan.  Very good movie!!!

It's 1903, and James M. Barrie (Johnny Depp) has just had a play flop resoundingly on the stage.  Anyone else might be crushed, but Barrie immediately sets out to write a new one.  While engrossed in this project, he unexpectedly encounters the four Llewellyn-Davies boys, George (Nick Roud), Jack (Joe Prospero), Peter (Freddie Highmore), and Michael (Luke Spill), whose mother Sylvia (Kate Winslet) was recently left a widow "with hardly a penny" (though she and her sons seem to live well enough).  A bond immediately forms between him and the boys--except for Peter, who has been left embittered by his father's death and unwilling to believe in anything, especially if it smells of fantasy--and he soon becomes "Uncle Jim," playing with the quartet and even lending the family his summer cottage.  Though the supposed relationship with Sylvia causes something of a scandal and alienates his wife (Radha Mitchell), Barrie finds himself inspired by it and writes a new play of a kind never seen before: the story of a boy who never grows up.

Depp's Barrie is a delightful "boy-man" with more than a touch of Captain Jack Sparrow about him (it's intriguing that he would have been cast as the creator of one of the best-known pirates in English literature), and the developing love of the four boys for this substitute father, plus the growing strain on his own marriage, is excellently done by all parties involved.  Dustin Hoffman appears as theatrical impresario Daniel Frohman, who's dubious about "Peter Pan" at first but takes the risk and, of course, finds he has an unprecedented hit on his hands.  This is a story about the importance of imagination and fantasy--and of balancing them with an awareness of reality.

Marc Forster's "Finding Neverland" (2004) is a perfect example of why Hollywood needs a moral makeover and a realignment of its spiritual compass.  The protagonist, Sir James Matthew Barrie (Johnny Depp), is played as a romantic hero, a champion of youth and childhood innocence. In reality he was an immature husband who cheated on his wife, a failed playwright, and a possible pedophile.  To soothe his troubled conscience, Depp's Sir James Barrie pursues a young widow, Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet), and her four sons.  As scandalous rumors begin to spread regarding Barrie's conduct, several characters, including Barrie's friends, his wife Mary Ansel (Radha Mitchell), and Sylvia's mother, Mrs. Emma du Maurier (Julie Christie), try to curb his involvement with the Llewelyn Davies family.  This seems to have the only effect of driving Barrie into more frequent contact with them.  The end result of Barrie's pursuit rings hollow.  Instead of cherishing his wife and building his family, Barrie loses Mary to another man.  Sylvia, the woman he was having an emotional affair with, ends up dying.  Equally tragic, "Neverland," the symbolic essence of Barrie's vision, passion, and dreams, is never shared with his wife Mary Ansel and is only incompletely and imperfectly shared with his mistress Sylvia.

Barrie's relationship with the four boys is also heartbreaking.  As a man he seems unable to give them wise counsel or to provide them with a good role model.  To the boys Barrie comes off as an older playmate, but their deepest fear is that he will try to replace their recently deceased but loving father.  In the film Barrie never is able to do more than get the boys to play and use their imagination, and in the end his only advice to the now orphaned children is to pretend that their mother is there.  "...in fact, she is, because she's on every page of your imagination. You'll always have her there. Always. ...And you can visit her any time you like if you just go there yourself. ...By believing, ...Just believe."  That Barrie ends up as the children's co-guardian is frightening.  That Sir Barrie never seems to have matured is amply demonstrated by the child Peter Llewelyn Davies (Freddie Highmore) when he states in the film, "I'm not Peter Pan," then points to Barrie and exclaims, "He is."  Johnny Depp's Sir James Matthew Barrie proves to indeed be this immature man who never seems to have grown up and lived in his own fantasy land.

On the surface - how is it possible for a successful, married playwright to fall in love with a widow with four little boys?  But this film shows one of the most tender love stories one can possibly imagine.

We have all grew up hearing the story about Peter Pan.  There were numerous movies made about the story too.  But how this story came to happen and who inspired it is the true root of this film.

Johnny Depp gives beautiful performance about the young playwright trying to find his own voice.  Stifled in unsuccessful marriage and bound by strict social conventions of the time, he and a young widow along with her four little boys form an alliance that is impossible to break.  This is a tender story about many forms of love: love for a soulmate and a muse, love of innocence lost in four little boys whose parents die all too soon, love of theatre and storytelling that creates a new kind of reality that is beautiful and generously offered to anyone willing to accept it.  This movie is a classic.

This is a lushly photographed, but ultimately rather flat film. Although it has a lot of star power, most of its popular actors fail to shine. Dustin Hoffman actually manages to be uninteresting as the long-suffering Producer of James Barrie's plays. Kate Winslet comes off as the somewhat conventional, dreary mother of a host of boys. Only one of these boys is allowed enough screen time to become a distinct character. Julie Christie appears as a one-dimensional harpy for most of the length of the film. Johnny Depp himself seems rather languorously abstracted into the fantasy world he periodically occupies with the boys.

Part of the reason for the actors' failure to give spark to their characters - might be that perennial pressure Directors are now under to maintain pacing. There is a Director's Commentary on this DVD, which is itself somewhat flat, but still probably worth listening to if you have the time. In this Commentary, Marc Forster tells how much of author James Barrie's biography he was compelled to cut in the interests of "keeping things moving." Some of the omissions he alludes to might make viewers wish that, instead of this movie, they had attended a performance of the "Lost Boys" play from which parts of "Finding Neverland" are loosely adapted.

For example, Depp (as Barrie) is seen briefly chatting with a man on the sidelines of a cricket game. The scene will probably completely fail to register with most viewers. But then the Director tells us that this fleeting exchange actually was the ten-second glimpse the film afforded into the abiding friendship between Barrie and Arthur Conan Doyle, inventor of Sherlock Holmes and himself a dedicated researcher into the mostly imaginary worlds beyond the veil. The scene would have been much more interesting if it had been given more time and detail. That's true of so many scenes.

Then the details that the Director did labor to include don't seem to count much. He points out how he would present two subtly different views of a setting or a character's dress. First we see Julie Christie's dress as it really is, Then when we turn back and see it again, it has changed ever so slightly, to reflect Barrie's heightened, imaginative view of it. However these changes are in fact so subtle, that it's doubtful they are registering, even subliminally, on most of us. It might have been more effective, more moving -  to just dwell on and flesh out the initial reality of the various scenes.

However, my somewhat dimmer view of the movie might just be a reflection of my lifelong indifference to the story of Peter Pan. As much as I like many of Barrie's other plays and stories, I was always left relatively cold, even as a child, by the play's philosophy - by its longing after the stasis of an eternal youth and by its early pop psychology purveyance of the idea that if you just believe - you can make it true. So the movie's lack of appeal for me might just be the result of the jaundiced view I've taken of the Peter Pan principle in general. Maybe those who really can believe in faeries - will find this a wonderland of a movie.

Finding Neverland is one of Johnny Depp's best performances.  Why?  Because you look at him and really believe that the dreams of a child still dwell within him.  That's part of the magic of Finding Neverland.  The blu-ray edition is beautiful to look at.  All of the make-believe sequences really stand out.  The audio is solid.  It only contains the special features from the regular DVD, but that's not a big selling point for me.  What is a selling point for me is that even in the face of adversity, this movie reminds you that you can believe whatever you want and make it real.  Watching the expressions of the children during the opening night of Peter Pan made me weep.  It was so wonderful to see the hope and joy in their eyes.  As an adult it's easy to get lost in the minutiae of everyday life, but this movie (as does The Diving Bell and the Butterfly) allows us to be as free as we want.  Imagination, memory, and will are all we need, and we can then go to Neverland.
