This is a terrific movie,"a Find"...It's a movie filled with a combination of humor,love,& sadness based upon real events!!!(The creation of Peter Pan.)It will be part of your permanent library.

FINDING NEVERLAND starring the actor Johnny Depp is a winner.  Depp has demonstrated over and over he is a multitalented actor who is best adapted to playing eccentric and/or magical men whether they sail pirate ships, delve in chocolate, or sculpt ice.  In this film the svelte Depp depicts the robust JM Barrie, author of Peter Pan and creator of Neverland.  Kate Winslett is counterpart, looks wonderful wearing the fashions from the early 20th century-large hats and big skirts- whether she plays an American heiress, an impoverished widow or an Oxford scholar. And, she can act, so her characters are poignant and believable, and the interaction is real.  Julie Christie as Winslett's mother is as beautiful as ever, while appearing maternal and stern. Dustin Hoffman is a wonderful foil to Depp as he plays the somewhat rational producer of his magical play. The little boys who play Winslett's sons and who along with their mother inspire the work are absolutely swell.

My sister warned me that the book and film were tear-jerkers, and the film is at least a three-hankie affair. It is also a beautiful magical film and I found myself saying "I believe in fairies" more than once, but particularly when Tinkerbell drinks the poisoned medicine to save Peter. The message, "What your mind can conceive and believe it will achieve" is stressed, although all the characters discover that denying something won't make it go away.

These days, I "screen" everything before I buy it, so I watched the rented version of the film, however, I like this DVD enough to buy it.

This movie is very emotional, but reminds us that remembering the imagination and curiousity of our youth is important.  Even though it is not a exact story of Peter pan, it's a great movie to watch and every adult and child of any age should watch it.

Although I fell asleep during the earlier parts of the movie, by the end I was choked up enough to make my girlfriend want to propose to me on the spot. Really guys, this movie is a great chance to show your ladies how emotional and vunerable you really are deep down inside, or at least to pretend so you can get some action. Finding Neverland is just full of  heartwarming moments, cute little kids with British accents, and a love story that works without any sex at all (and probably because of it). Honestly, this movie is so nice, it makes Peter Pan, the play it's based around, look like Die Hard.

First, when I say "not a kid's movie" I do not mean that it contains anything inappropriate for children, but simply that most kids will be disappointed if they watch it based on the ads they saw for it on TV.  Despite me stating that the plot of Neverland is "predictable", I found that the way it was marketed left me completely surprised when I purchased the DVD.  I was left expecting a show that was fantastical and sort of a "real life Peter Pan story."  This movie is instead a poignant story of a young boy dealing with the death of his Father, illness in his Mother, while developing a mature and unique relationship with the man who would write the play that became "Peter Pan".  Depp's character borrows from the imagination of this pained youth to develop Peter Pan while attempting to provide the boy with a safe harbor in which to express and deal with the obvious pain he feels.

If you're looking for a sophisticated quasi love story with a back drop of the real and imagined creation of Peter Pan, you'll probably enjoy this movie.  I prefer movies with happy endings, and this one doesn't fit that bill (at least for me).  The peformances of Depp and Winslet are everything you'd expect.  The performance of Freddie Highmore, who plays the key young man (Peter, of course), is almost itself enough to make this movie worth watching.

Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet. Another movie with a high hotness factor. That's never a bad thing. Peter Pan is one of my favorite stories ever and so it was kind of a given that I'd love this movie. Plus, how can you NOT love Johnny Depp? I loved the fuzzy line between real and make-believe. The cinematography was beautiful, the acting was superb, and the story was moving. An all-around winner that I'll be enjoying again, I'm sure. It's a definite To Buy DVD.

I went into this movie expecting it to be very cheesy and very sappy.  To my surprise, it was neither of the two.  Unfortunately, I also thought it might be a little boring and I was right on that assumption.  I had a hard time getting into the movie until about halfway through.  Depp, Winslet, and the children were all very good in the movie.  There was a definite chemistry between the actors that came across.  The best part of the movie is at the end when Winslet goes to Neverland.  That's really, to me, the only stand out scene in the movie.  The story was a little sad without being depressing or draining.  It was funny without being over the top, and it was thoughtful without sounding like a Hallmark commercial.  It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'll be rushing out to buy it.

Marc Forster's "Finding Neverland" is the best tale of artistic inspiration since "Amadeus."  In that amazing film about Mozart, some of the most enjoyable scenes focused on how Mozart could find inspiration for a musical composition in the dribble composed by a rival, or even in the shrieking of his mother-in-law.  "Amadeus" left you bewildered at the scope of Mozart's genius.

"Finding Neverland" shows the inspiration of a talented author that comes from a different source -- love and lost innocence.  The author, J.M. Barrie (Johnny Depp, once again magnificent), is trapped both in a loveless marriage and by the social mores of 1903 England.  His latest play is a flop, and his curmudgeonly backer, Charles Frohman (Dustin Hoffman, redeeming himself for the disastrous "Hook"), is dropping ominous hints about Barrie's future.

And then, lo and behold, Barrie stumbles across the Widow Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet) and her four little boys.  Instantly tapping into the active imaginations of these kids, Barrie is soon playing pirates, or cowboys and Indians, or any number of games involving imagination with the tykes.  Out of these games, and also thanks to the harsh discipline vainly imposed by the Sylvia's mother Emma (Julie Christie), the classic tale of "Peter Pan" is born.

"Finding Neverland" skirts cheap manipulation but always stays on the side of effective restraint.  Watch for several tear-jerker scenes, especially the perfect choice Barrie makes to ensure on "Peter Pan's" opening night that the older theater audience "gets" the play.  But the cast never goes over the top, and this saves the movie.

And while each of the kids in the movie provides performances ranging from good to great, special mention has to be made for Freddie Highmore as Peter.  This little guy is freakishly good, and says more with a glance than many adult actors can do with a rambling speech.

A heck of a family film that never descends into mawkishness, "Finding Neverland," like "Peter Pan," has several delights that are worth (and include) a few tears along the way.  Check it out.

Johnny Depp plays a guy named James Matthew Barrie, who is a guy who writes plays, and not too many people like them. Later in the movie, he is claimed to be Peter Pan. That's really all this movie is about. I just have one question about Peter Pan...why is he always played by a woman?? Answer:I don't know. Maybe it just seems right, but not to me. Basically, this movie had barely anything to do with Neverland. Even though that is the case, there is one scene where Kate Winslet is shown Neverland. That's about it, and they talk a whole lot about stuff like it and James Matthew Barrie was saying to "Believe" at the end. I didn't think this was awful. Only alright. It's worth seeing.

This movie is one to add to your collection!  It tells the amazing story behind the creator of "Peter Pan."  The 4 boys that influenced J.M. Barrie and the woman that he fell in love with, all helped him to imagine a story about a boy who would never grow up.  It is a truely touching film that will leave you breathless at its end.  Johnny Depp and Kate Winslett have incredible chemistry and absolutly makes the story work in the end!
The CD is faulty.  It plays abour half was through, and then starts over again. I cannot get it to play all the was to the end.

This is one of my favorite movie! it has an excellant cast with Johnny depp and the wonderful kate Winlset. It's a cute, touching story about the creation of 'Neverland' and children's classic Peter Pan. I highly recommend this movie it's great!!!

This is a charming film.  Barrie seems to have found Never Land and considers his mission in life is to guide others to this magical place.  It appears to be less of a biography than a kind of road map to what many would consider to be a fantasy world.

It would be nice to find a refuge from our corporeal world, where we can live out fantasies and reconnect with those who have departed.  It is also refreshing to find a story of this search for Never Land without the injection of a divinity or mention of religous values.

this is one of the best films of 2004.  johnny depp and kate winslet are great together.  being a huge fan of the story of peter pan, i loved every minute of this story.  it's truly a treasure.  because of it's low recognition by the oscars, this film has been quite overlooked and tossed aside.  i highly recommend seeing this film if you have not.

I watched this film in theaters; it was magical and Johnny delivered a masterful performance. And of course, Kate Winslet is a genius at acting. I found myself completely engrossed in the plot, which is very poignant and beautiful. The ending made me cry...

The movie starts out a bit slow ... but as it builds and builds it embraces the audience. It is truly a beautiful movie, probably one of Johnny Dep's best. The portrayal of Barrie's journey to develop Peter Pan makes for an interesting and thoroughly touching story, even if it does occasionally wander into melodrama. Fans of Kate Winslet will enjoy her wonderful performance as Carrie's muse and Hoffman's role, though small, is hilarious. The movie basically plays up on the relationship he develops with 4 boys who play sons of Kate Winslett. They become his inspiration for writing Peter Pan. Even having said that, it can't begin to discribe how moving and touching the entire movie plays out. Johnny Dep brings out the kid in all of us. The movie has the perfect balance of humor and sadness

Finding Neverland is a great movie and i happen to be a huge fan of peter pan and i thought that this movie was awesome at retelling a beloved classic fairy tale!!!!!!!! It has hotie Johnny Depp and the beautiful and talented Kate Winslet and its about peter pan and the adventures that peter goes on everyday without the neverland!!!!!!! This movie is a must for peter pan fans and what more can i say just go and rent this movie!!!!!

This is a beautiful film.  It is extremely well done and is a wonderful fantasy dedicated to the idea that what we wish life could be can be so if we only believe hard enough.  It is about the writing of Peter Pan by James Matthew Barrie.  We all know that world of make believe and magic this parable has for us as it has had for audiences and readers for more than 100 years.

The movie says that its telling of this story is inspired by true events.  Yes, but with great liberties.  It is itself a fantasy of how the story "should" have been.  I won't bother telling you all the liberties taken with the way life actually was because you can simply search the web for Barrie's full name and find all the biographical detail you want, but like all facts it might destroy some of the beautiful wishing the movie inspires.  So, be careful what it is you want to know.

The actors do a splendid job.  While I usually have mixed emotions about Johnny Depp, he is masterful in this performance.  Kate Winslet as the comsumptive Sylvia Llewelyn Davies makes the movie by being the foundation for Barrie's relationship with her boys, the true love of Barrie, however chaste, and the vehicle for the tragedy that makes the ending so poignant and strengthening the argument for making reality through belief.  Julie Christie plays Sylvia's mother who dislikes Barrie and does a great job as the  bucket of cold water on all this make believe stuff.  And Dustin Hoffman brings just the right touch as the good natured impresario who backs Barrie's plays without really understanding what Barrie is really about.

So, this is a fable about Barrie and one you might prefer to believe to the reality of the man and the lives of those involved.  Yet, I think you can have both.  What is given us here is something worth experiencing and remembering.  However, it is only the story of the author of Peter Pan in the broad strokes.  Somehow, doesn't making a fantasy about the life of a person who could imagine Neverland seem perfectly appropriate?  Yes, but remembering what it was he really did and how things really happened is also important.

But see this film.  It is very well done.

Some movies are great because of their fine acting, some because of their fascinating stories, others because of their depth of character and still others because of the moods they evoke.  And then there are those rare films that seem to have it all.

This movie has it all.

From amazing performances, to believable and likeable characters, to a fascinating, original storyline, to laughter and tears, Finding Neverland does not disappoint on any level.

Johnny Depp is truly amazing.  There is no other actor who can create original characters and make them multidimensional the way Depp can.  Depp's Barrie is a shy, sensitive, creative genius filled with warmth and humor. I can't imagine any other actor who could play Barrie with that kind of believability.  Pitt?  Too shallow and untested.  Cruise?  Too self-involved.  Crowe?  Too rough around the edges.  (Pay attention during the parlor scene in Sylvia's house when James relates to Sylvia the story of his mother after the death of James's brother.  He has never spoken of his unique fantasy--Neverland--to anyone before this, he tells her.  Depp's delivery is remarkable.  Watch the subtle movements in his expression.  The eyes, the shy smile.  Incredible.)

And Kate Winslet puts in an outstanding performance as Sylvia, a woman who has her priorities in the right places.  She made me want to go home, trade my PC for Play-Doh and spend my time with my kids.

Although I don't think Depp and Winslet are an obvious couple, and there's never anything physical between Sylvia and James, the depth of love shown by these characters is obvious and genuine. Once again, it would be hard to picture other actors in their places.

Freddie Highmore's performance as Peter is garnering all the attention, and rightfully so, but all the boys are extraordinary.  They are so convincing that it is hard to believe these boys are from the present century.  There's not a one who doesn't represent his character as if he were in fact a Llewellyn Davies.

The scenery and the music also evoke another, more innocent era, strengthening the mood of the film.

Even the fringe characters--Radha Mitchell as cold Mary Barrie, Dustin Hoffman as James's dry-humored business manager, and Julie Christie as Sylvia's stern, protective mother--hit the mark.

And director Marc Forster was robbed of an opportunity to win an Oscar, having not even been nominated.  The scenes are so original, so well-thought-through, they are Oscar worthy by far.

Anyone who appreciates a warm story filled with rich performances will find Finding Neverland rewarding.

I saw all of the candidates for the Oscar, and still feel that Johnny Depp and Finding Neverland should have won in the Best Actor and Best Film categories.  Depp is probably the most talented and versatile actor in the world today, and the movie was terrific -- a wonderful addition to his brilliant portfolio.  He is in a class by himself.

Entertaining at times but dull in many parts.  Overall, I didn't enjoy this movie.  It was produced well and the acting was good, but the storyline overly glorified Barrie, making him seem like a saint, and it failed to interest me.  It also altered Barrie's life too much for me to appreciate the film.

In truth Barrie fell in love with Sylvia Llewelyn Davies while her husband Arthur was still alive and practically moved in with the family--one of those types of guests that you can't get rid of. The husband didn't approve of Barrie spending so much time with his wife and children. Can you blame him?  I would look upon someone who had such an interest in my children with suspicion.  In fact, it has often been suggested that Barrie was a pedophile and molested the children though no proof has ever been found to support that suspicion. Some claim he was asexual.

At any rate Mr. Davies unsuccessfully kept Barrie away from his family even after he'd moved his family many miles away to put some distance between them and the writer. Arthur soon died and then Sylvia, and Barrie did in fact get custody of the children.

I believe that the true events of Barrie's life are far more interesting than what was revealed in this film. Had his life been accurately portrayed, including the dirt, this would have been a much better film.

"Finding Neverland" is a very enchanting, emotional, and fantastic movie. I laughed. I cried.  "My heart blew up like a balloon." (I'm quoting a movie there.)

Johnny Depp is such an amazing actor, and he brought J.M. Barrie to life in a wonderful way.

If you are a fan of Barrie, Peter Pan, and fantastically filmed movies that the whole family can enjoy, rent it, buy it!

You will enjoy the journey to Neverland.

Eileen Famiglietti

"Finding Neverland" is that rare gem of a movie that takes its audience seriously.  So many of the movies out of Hollywood are geared towards the 16 to 25 year old male perspective.  Action, dumb plot, stupid characters, etc.  "Neverland" is a movie that doesn't pander to emotion.  It doesn't show us yet another unnecessary action scene.  And it doesn't make every relationship obsessed with sex.

What you get with "Neverland" is a movie that takes you to another time and gives you insight into the mind of a great writer and the experiences which influenced him.  It is a patient movie, more interested in creating a tone and place to help us understand the concepts of Neverland, imagination, and reality.

While perhaps not the focus of the director (and probably unnoticed by most viewers), "Neverland" is also a refreshing depiction of a male character dealing with children.  While Barrie is depicted as being child-like, he is still a grown man with an adult's ability in relating to children.  Far too often we're inundated with media images of the stupid father figure, the doofus, who doesn't have a clue.  With Depp's characterization of Barrie we see a man who can play with children and yet still be an adult.

Johnny Depp, almost as matter of course, once again delivers a performance that is all the more amazing given his body of work as a whole.  This the same man who did "Pirates of the Caribbean," "What's Eating Gilbert Grape," and a dozen other movies in widely divergent character roles.  And Kate Winslet seems to be only getting better with age, both in ability and beauty.

There seems to be a number of reviewers claiming that "Neverland" is slow or that it's pretentious.  If you enjoy well made movies you can ignore these comments.  Of course, don't fall prey to the hype, either.  "Finding Neverland" might not become your most favorite film, but it is worth both viewing and owning as a DVD.  I can't say that about too many films these days.

Here is some honest advice. If you really need to see this movie, by all means, don't rent it or buy it. You will only be adding dishonest dollars to the producers of this movie. Find someone who already has the movie and see it. You will understand why the rest of the movie goers have given this horrid movie a thumbs down. If you really need to know what this movie is about without wasting your money and time, just read the synopsis of this movie on this website. Just don't believe the overblown reviews.

Johnny Depp was perfectly cast in Finding Neverland, and the children showed acting ability beyond their ages. At times I had difficulty believing Kate Winslet's proformance, but I was still crying by the end.
This is a very sensitive look at the difficult issue of death of a parent to view with children. Children can worry and this could be a starting point to talk.

Biopics are never going to be as good as other kinds of movies.  Too many people will be watching it knowing that facts are fudged to make better cinema.  And that's what has happened here.

On the other hand you have Johnny Depp at the top of his form, acting with a really very well done Northern accent that was probably tweaked very slightly in post-production.  I thought that the picture was a little muddled up--was it supposed to show that Barrie was so imaginative that he saved the lives of the Llewellyn Davies boys, or was it the other way around?  And if it was both, then why was it so sad?  Anyone watching the movie would assume that Mary, Mrs. Barrie, the character played by Radha Mitchell, was a social climber in 1904 and that she aspired to get to know Emma Du Maurier (the Julie Christie part) because of Christie's superior social status.  That's just all wrong and the screenwriters must have known this.  There was not this enormous social distance between the two families, both were well-known in theatrical circles but as anyone knows, that was a very louche occupation a hundred years ago, no guarantee of respectability.

After the film was over, I realized I had been so captivated by the superior performances of Depp, Christie, Winslet and little Freddie Highmore that I didn't even care.  Was Barrie supposed to have been in love with Sylvia?  I didn't get that in the movie, until quite late, when little Peter lashes out at Barrie saying something like, "My mother never cared for you the way she cared for my father!"  Johnny Depp didn't even look that upset, just concerned that his boys not suffer too much from her absence.

I wish they would make a sequel that would show the horrible things that happened to the four boys in the rough years that were to follow the Edwardian age.  Was it worth it?  Who's to say!  Another bonus is the remarkable acting of Kelly Macdonald (GOSFORD PARK) who plays "Peter Pan" on stage at the theater.  Don't you love the outtakes part of the disc which shows her slamming repeatedly into walls on her harness?  Ouch!  Luckily her beauty, charm and wit remain intact.

I was really trying to understand why this film seemed to appeal to some people, (outside of all the bogus reviews written here by obvious plants from the industry) and have concluded that it is a film loved by anglophiles and wannabe upper class ladder climbers. Why else could such a totally boring film be considered a good film? It is not the writing, as it is pure boring drivel. It is not the content, as it is boring as well. It is not the acting, because all the actors are as inspired as concrete. The fascination with this movie lies in the typical neurotic/psycosis of middle white america and the dreams of these people returning to a period of time where there were no "problems" living with other races and other classes. The setting of the movie is sterile with not a colored face to be found. Truly, the only problem that the main character has is his abnormal interest in a married woman's children. This is, in a nutshell, what this movie is about.

The critics rave and the duped film going audience is fooled into thinking that this movie is stellar. Glowing empty headed reviews reveal the inability of these movie goers to understand that the movie is bad; the attraction being that they are drawn to their inner desires to be in a period of time where they can be free of the raging "common" masses. This is why they praise and enjoy this movie. This movie is a sham in everyway, and the glowing reviews only are a bald faced attempt to sell a very boring movie. I cannot fanthom the utter depravity and sheer dumbness and braindead premise of this film. The only saving grace to "Finding Neverland" is that it shows that the movie going public has proven that it is not smart enough to understand that they have been fooled into accepting such a piece of trash as "good film making." This is good news because this means that any of us can make movies such as Finding Neverland and get rich.

This is the worse movie made in recent film history. If you doubt this, go ahead, make my day and watch it. Don't say I didn't warn you.

Playwright James Barrie (Johnny Depp) is having a hard time finding inspiration until he runs into the recently bereaved children of Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet).  In trying to cheer the four boys and their mother up, Barrie opens a door in his own mind---and begins to see pirates and Indians.  Thus, the "Peter Pan" story is born from his play with the children.

As time goes on, Barrie's friendship with Davies and her children begins to interfere with his own rocky marriage.  Also, Davies' mother (Julie Christie) is angry that Barrie is taking up the young widow's time when she should be seeking suitors instead.

Overall, it's a fascinating and enjoyable movie.  I don't know how true to life it is.  I'm not sure I want to find out.  This is one you can take your kids to -- it's real without being too sweet or full of self pity.  Very well done all around.

Folks, I like movies. I like good movies. I don't care what kind of movie is out there, if it is good, I'll like it...and if it is a bad one, I won't like it. Pure and simple.

What kind of movie is Finding Neverland? In short, a very bad one. I believe this movie has snob appeal. Just as wines gather a certain amount of snob appeal, so does Finding Neverland gather its share of snobbery moss. There is no denying that the idea of the movie is a good one, and that is where the positives of this movie end. The acting is just horrible, or maybe it is the directing that stinks. The movie never grabs you and is as phony as a three dollar bill. Just because a movie seems foriegn, does not make it a good movie. Some people have touted this movie as a great family movie. I would think that watching grass grow would be more fun. Your kids, (and adults, if they are honest enough) will see through this sorry excuse of a movie and see it for what it is, a snobby 'art' film.

I readily admit to being one of those "shallow" movie fans, who would probably prefer to watch a badly acted, formulaic action thriller to a timeless classic if given the choice.  Needless to say, I was not expecting to enjoy (or for that matter, even sit through) Finding Neverland when my wife popped it in the DVD player last weekend.

What followed is one of the most imaginative and artistic movies I have ever seen.  While inspired by the story of J.M. Barrie's authoring of Peter Pan, Finding Neverland is really more fantasy than documentary.  The movie is visually captivating, taking place both in the "real world" and in J.M. Barrie's active imagination.  There is at least one scene that brilliantly crosses the two over, but I do not want to spoil the movie for those who have not seen it.  Needless to say, those who have seen the movie will know what I'm talking about, and those who haven't will understand as soon as they see the movie.

Overall, the style of the movie is a bit reminiscent of Big Fish, another movie that I enjoyed despite expecting that I wouldn't last through the whole thing.  Needless to say, those with active imaginations who generally enjoy fantasies will love this movie.  Those expecting a historical piece will probably be disappointed, which perhaps explains some of the negative reviews I have seen.

Johnny Depp's performance is outstanding, although in watching the movie, I remembered a conversation I had with a friend about Robin Williams' performance in Dead Poet's Society.  He told me, "yes, Robin Williams is a good actor, but this movie is really about the kids."  In many respects, Finding Neverland is the same kind of movie.  Johnny Depp turns in an Oscar-caliber performance (although I won't argue with the Academy's selection of Jamie Foxx in Ray), but is in many respects outshined by the children, who are so central to this movie.  Kate Winslet, never one of my favorites, turns in a serviceable performance: think Titanic, and not Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

I put my name on the list at the public library and waited patiently for my turn to view "Finding Neverland". I'm glad I didn't get too pumped up about it meanwhile, or I would have been  disappointed. I had thought that this movie would be something of a biography of James M. Barrie, the author of Peter Pan, but it hardly qualifies as such.

We are not given much insight into Mr. Barrie's character or behavior, or that of anyone else featured in the film, for that matter. What we get are essentially one-dimensional stick figures. J.M. Barrie (Johnny Depp) meets four children and their widowed mother (Kate Winslet) in the park while walking his dog. Suddenly they all become inseparable, much to the chagrin of Barrie's wife (Radha Mitchell) and Winslet's character's mother (Julie Christie). For the most part, the adults (excepting perhaps the Christie character) are too busy being dignified to show emotion or reveal their motivation(s). Mr. Barrie maintains a certain stateliness even when playing with the children, often while wearing a three-piece suit.

The result is a film which fails to hook the viewer, who is also unable to get emotionally involved. Hence the movie, while not unpleasant, is not especially memorable either. Despite an A-List cast, it seemed as though they were all directed to "act inhibited". Consequently, my delight as a viewer was inhibited as well. Let me point out that I'm essentially a minimalist who as a rule appreciates understatement and despises sensationalism. Yet despite that, there was just too much of something(s) missing from this effort.

I read many glowing reviews on this site and others. These reviews were very eloquent, almost suspiciously so. I have always wondered if the studios pay people to write reviews on online sites. This movie strongly confirms this suspicion. I can't believe I am seeing the same movie these people watched. I was barely able to sit through the whole thing. It is just too slow and predictable.
One of the most beautiful movies I've seen.  A must see for those of you who love to get lost in the movies you watch.
Who would want to find Neverland, just so they can never grow up like Peter Pan what a childish name for a movie. Johnny Depp is too good to be playing in boring movies like this.

This film was absolutely flawless! Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet deliver breathtaking performances with a great supporting cast including Dustin Hoffman and Julie Christie. Finding Neverland perfectly creates the inspiration that lead J.M. Barrie to write the beloved "Peter Pan" and has the situation with the family mirror what Barrie writes in the play.

It also does an excellent job of merging fantasy and reality in many scenes, and it gives even adults that suspension of disbelief, that feeling of letting the imagination take flight, with no inhibitions whatsoever.

This movie deserved an Oscar!

Bravo!

This movie is the story of how JM Barrie came up with his ideas for Peter Pan and the first showing of the play.  I am not a critic but I know what I like.

I did not really like this movie overall, but I liked parts of it enough to give it three stars.

I think Johnny Depp is awesome in almost every thing he stars in and he is equally as good in this.  His accent was great and he really made me feel like he was the kid at heart who could create a place such as Neverland and have us believe.  It was as though he became the man he was playing.

I did not really care for Kate Winslet or her character but this could be because the character was not fleshed out as much.  She was merely a woman who went along for the ride as JM Barrie and her children bonded. The movie gave no insight into why she was so willing to just go along with them or why she neglected her health when she was the only parent her children had.  However, to Ms. Winslet's credit, the same could be argued of most of the other characters.  The only character who we were given any insight into was Mr. Barrie.

THE STORY:

Mr. Barrie had just made a play that flopped and then he was moping in the park and met 4 boys and their mother.  The boys are sad over the recent death of their father.  He starts to spend time with them and he brings out their ability to use their imagination and to create plays.  He then starts to create his vision of Neverland and his characters of Peter Pan and the Lost Boys.

I liked alot of this movie because it showed how absolutely wonderful imagination is and how it can make you flourish, the way it did for the boys.  Also, it showed how stuffy and unimaginative we are as adults and sometimes it takes a child to show us how to enjoy ourselves.  I won't ruin a great scene by telling it here.

As I said, all in all, it was a goood movie but I would not have nominated it for an Oscar.

I tried to like this movie, I really did, but it just didn't hit a chord with me. The movie is loosely based on the life of J.M. Barrie, the writer of the `Peter Pan' story. The writers of the movie manipulated the facts to get a warm fuzzy effect of the movie that I guess is supposed to leave you feeling inspired, though it didn't with me.

Basically, the plot is rather mediocre. To sum up, Barrie meets a widowed woman and her son's in the park and they develop a friendship. Actually, I would consider Barrie more than just a `family friend'; he takes it a step further in my opinion. However, the writers of the movie made it obvious that their friendship was totally asexual (even with the mother). Essentially, the rest of the movie is him pretend-playing with these boys, thusly getting the inspiration for his famous play, `Peter Pan'. In the middle of this his wife gets annoyed that he's spending so much time with this family and leaves him (who could blame her). I won't say anything else about the plot because I don't want to spoil it, but that's pretty much it in a nut shell. The concept of the story is great; triumph of art, creativity, and playfulness over snootiness and growing-up.  However, I feel it was poorly executed in the movie. The acting and the visuals were pretty good, but the plot seriously lacked momentum.

On a side note, it's funny how the movie completely mirrors Michael Jackson. You have a man who, for some reason, has this need to fill a void in his life by pretend-playing with young boys. This man completely refuses to `grow-up' and take on the normal responsibilities of adulthood such as tending to relationships and commitments.

This movie is good for a rental. It's really nothing great.

I agree with T burger.  I did do some research after watching this & the main point of the movie is the same.  He created this world after meeting & falling in love with those boys.  If they made every movie that's based on fact word for word they would probably be boring.  They're usually loosely based & meant more to entertain than to inform.  I loved it.  Story, great, sets, great.  Johnny Depp Double great.

Marc Forster's FINDING NEVERLAND isn't a bad movie, I suppose. In its depiction of playwright J.M. Barrie's creation of the classic PETER PAN, it has its occasional moments of real wide-eyed wonder (mostly during re-enactments of moments in the actual play), and it has generally fine performances from its cast---not even the prestige-pic atmosphere of this movie can keep the wide-ranging actor Johnny Depp down. And, of course, the movie looks sumptuous and handsome (which counts for something in my book).

But FINDING NEVERLAND is yet another example of the kind of sentimental, non-threatening tripe that Hollywood has a tendency to produce and foist upon the masses during Oscar season. This particular Oscar-bait picture has as its mantra "Just believe," but the movie rarely ever elicits the same sense of innocent wonder that this film's Barrie clearly believes in. (Its brief "fantasy" sequences---which includes Barrie dancing with a dog, or Barrie playing a pirate with a widower's kids---are too cheesily done to make us believe in anything.) Nor does it have much of a sharp edge to its potentially disturbing depiction of a writer's sudden fixation on the widower's kids; his attraction to the innocence of these kids---at least, in most of the kids; one of them, played by Freddie Highmore, still carries the pain and anger of loss with him---is depicted (and romanticized) by Forster and screenwriter David Magee as mostly pure and rather beautiful. (Yea right; so is Michael Jackson's, too?) By smoothing away almost all of the rough edges, by manipulating events to fit its banal message, by toning down Johnny Depp's usual actorly exuberance, Marc Forster comes up with a film that, for all its impressive production values, is never very intellectually stimulating. It's insufferably pleasant rather than challenging. Is it deeply moving? For me, not really; when Forster finally unveils his visual depiction of Neverland towards the end, it is mawkish rather than transporting; so is its final scene, in which Barrie tells disillusioned young Peter Davies to "just believe" that his relatives still live on.

Look, it's a nice idea, to be able to hold on to your child-like innocence and all that. But, just because you become an adult, that doesn't mean you have to lose your imagination or sense of child-like wonder. (That's one of the things movies can do best---but not this movie.) But it's hardly a good idea either to be as child-like as this film's Barrie is; in this difficult world, you'd never survive if your only purpose in life was to remain an innocent child throughout, the way Barrie tries to be. Growing up is something everybody has to do; it's something FINDING NEVERLAND apparently doesn't believe in. It's better to remain a naive kid rather than live in the real world. And of course this potentially dangerous philosophy gets applause from gullible viewers who find the movie "enchanting": it's a fantasy that appeals to them, which is precisely why I think the film is intellectually empty. Sorry if that sounds terribly cynical, but that personal reaction to the film's message is the only way I can explain why there was only one scene in the movie that genuinely moved me: a scene in which an angry Peter Davies shouts out to Barrie, "I will not be lied to." It's the only scene with any real dramatic weight to it, because it is the closest the movie comes to challenging its own sentimental, simple-minded "just believe" philosophy. Peter has glimpsed the cold, hard reality of death, and is trying to deal with it in his own way; this film's Barrie, instead, would probably try to tell himself that no one ever really dies, as long as his/her memory is kept alive. Again, a comforting notion; but it can be plain delusional to deny the harsh reality of death.

FINDING NEVERLAND is well-made enough that it's worth the 3 stars I'm granting it here. The movie probably makes worthy family entertainment; there's nothing all that offensive for parents to get too worried about. But if you're expecting something truly insightful or deeply moving from this trite Hollywood prestige pic, you might be disappointed. For all of its adult pretensions, FINDING NEVERLAND is, at heart, as childish as its real-life hero.

Johnny Depp put in a good performance in this movie. And that's the problem. I expect an actor of his caliber to show me something on the screen that will blow me away every single time. (Sorry about that,  but Johnny has spoiled me). Instead what I saw was an actor reigned in. Did the money-mafia intercede somewhere along the line and say "no funny stuff..we're going for main stream here. Think Oscar."  Kate Winslet just was not credible in the role of a woman dying of a progressive, wasting disease.  Really?!  When Barrie finally reveals Neverland to her, supposedly on the eve of her death, she looks like nothing but the beautiful English girl that she is. As fresh and as robust as the proverbial milkmaid. As for Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman...what about them? Their parts could of been played by actors of lesser talent and the final product would not have suffered for it . This is not the worst movie ever made but it's got to be the worst misuse of acting talent in recent history. Finding Neverland is a medicore commercial product. The invitation implied gourmet but on arrival I got fast food. And I really, really  wanted to LIKE this movie.

Although I understand that J. M. Barrie was not perfect, there is no reason to relate him to the "Michael Jackson" scandal. It might be true that he *was* a pedophile, but in this movie, nothing of the sort was shown. The movie is *based* upon events that happened in the past, but is not a documentary of any sort or kind, and therefore cannot be deemed untruthful. Since the movie is not a historical film, nor does it portray any sort of pedophilia, it is unjust to give this movie a bad review for the past events.

Depp came across as a truly kind being who became very close with a family, and especially with that family's kids. He enjoyed being around them because maybe he felt that they needed a father figure, or maybe that he saw himself in the children and just wanted to have fun with them because he had no children of his own. Depp played Barrie in a manner which might have not been accurate, but his performance was amazing.

Winslet, who as well gives a rather good performance, fits with Depp like pieces of a puzzle, and the dynamics between Depp and the boys are amazing in all scenarios.

Overall, this was a stunning movie, and never you mind the reviews that say that this film was boring or stupid. This brings out emotion in almost everyone, from kids to seniors, and the only people who don't find it interesting are those who dislike a movie that actually has a good plot/doesn't have "action"/actually has in-depth characters.

I HIGHLY HIGHLY RECCOMEND THAT YOU PUT THIS ON THE TOP OF YOUR LIST TO RENT OR BUY. I GUARANTEE THAT IF YOU WATCH IT ONCE, JUST ONCE, YOU WILL FALL IN LOVE WITH IT IMMEDIATELY.

Finding Neverland.  The movie is absolutely breathtaking.  I love everything about it from the costumes, to the script, from the actors, to the cinematography art direction.  The viewer gets to witness how the story, "Peter Pan" came to be.  Actor Johnny Depp not just plays the part but transforms into "Peter Pan" Scottish playwright J.M. Barrie.  Watching this sent chills down my back -- the sign of a spectacular performance.  I was mesmerized while watching Finding Neverland.  I felt as if I leaped from my seat into each scene.  This film gets 5 stars!

the extrodorinary life of James Matthew Barrie is like a real life fairy tale, who brought out the imagination in children, pretend your pirates on the sea, pretend your Cowboys and Indians. Finding Neverland is the biographical story of playwright and author of the flying boy who didn't grow up, J.M. Barrie and the woman and boys who he put a joyus effect on as they inspired his classic tale of Pirates,Indians,Mermaids and a flying boy. This is a beautiful picture, an imaginative triumph of a man's imagination, it's extrodinary, a magical masterpiece. Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet are sensational. J.M. Barrie must be a inspiration for Walt Disney, because did an adaptation of "Peter Pan". One of the best biographical films among "the Aviator" and "Chaplin"If you want a great biographical film, See "Finding Neverland" because by watching this masterpiece you'll find Neverland. A film that explores one man's imagination and the family who loved him for it

This 2004 film is about the writer of the beloved tale of Peter Pan.  Johnny Depp is cast in the lead role of Sir James Barrie, a married London playwright whose career is failing.  However, when he meets a young widow, played by Kate Winslet, and her four young boys, he becomes a friend of that family, much to the displeasure of his own wife as well as the widow's mother, played by Julie Christie.  These are fine roles for all of them.  And the story held my interest.  However, even though the film is set in 1903, I couldn't help viewing it through modern eyes.  And basically, I feel repugnance for a man who just can't grow up, loves to play with children as if he is one of them, and finds his greatest happiness when he is doing just that.  Even the name "Neverland" is a turn-off for me.

Personal views aside though, I did enjoy the costumes and sets of the period.  I also thought the performances were excellent.  That's why I give this film a mild recommendation.

This movie made me want to read Peter Pan and see every feature film based on his story. Suddenly you see films like "New Adventures in Neverland" by Disney or "Hook" with Robin Williams in a brand new light. I like the fact that this movie is not a mere biographical portrait of J.M.Barrie. It makes the author part of Peter Pan's world and thus links our real world with Neverland.

Certainly, you cannot expect to learn facts and figures about 19th century literature or Barrie's personal relations, but you'll find a new aspect of your own world which makes this movie absolutely worth watching. It's a must. Honestly.

"Finding Neverland", "Lost in Translation", and "The Girl With the Pearl Earring" are all some sort of quiet yet beautiful works which I regard more like a painting than like a plot-based story.

One more thing: Johnny Depp makes a great perfomance and leaves enough room for a little English boy whose wet eyes will eventually make you sad and probably even cry.

This movie seems like a film that Hollywood is increasingly unable or unwilling to make, or at least unable to make well. Consider the following two facts about Finding Neverland: (a) there is virtually no profanity or sex and (b) it features a protagonist who is able to have a platonic, mature relationship with a woman who is not his wife, a relationship that he partakes in solely for the good of the woman and her family. But I think I liked the film mostly because it deals with one of my favorite topics: the human imagination. Some movies (Star Wars, etc.) are exercises in the human imagination, but don't really delve into how the exercise of imagination can affect normal everyday life. There is a tendency in some people to discount "escapist" cinema as being less worthy of artistic or cultural merit than movies that deal with "real" subjects. But as this movie shows, the fantastic can influence the real world in meaningful ways, and vice versa. It is the relationship with the widow's four sons that provided the impetus for J. M. Barrie to write his classic "Peter Pan" stageplay, and in Barrie's overactive imagination the boys found the strengh to deal with very real tragedies that had befallen their young lives. As C. S. Lewis (a writer of the fantastic whose relationship with another woman's sons is strangely similar to Barrie's) once commented, the only people who object to escapism are jailers.

The movie only fudged a couple of facts.  Of course, sugar-coating omissions in this manner is acceptable to those hoping to paint a perfect portrait of J. M. Barrie.  That said, upon reviewing Barrie's life and his relationship with the Llewelyn Davies children, many psychologists and psychiatrists view Barrie as a pedophile.  I know, I know.  It's all heresay, right?  I was all heresay against Michael Jackson too, until someone couldn't keep the secret any longer.
Finding Neverland is an emotional movie that will leave you crying.  It's a sweet movie, that have some excellent performances, especially from the children.

This is one of the best movies of the year. It sucks you right in to the imaginitive mind of JM Barrie, creator of Peter Pan, and gives you a glimpse into what his life was like. A heartwarming tear-jerker, it's destined to become a fast classic. After seeing it only once, I knew I had to own it, and it is loved (in my experience) by men and women of all ages (it's not a chick flick!) Highly HIGHLY recommended.
Do yourself a favor and skip to the ending, that way you can get to the point of the story. The story is slow and boring.

I understand that no one is perfect, and everyone has flaws, and I suppose every talented actor has his or her dismal film, and this one bored me to death. I have respect for Johnny Deep, in so many ways, however this film just wasn't for him.

Every so often there comes along a movie that is just so wonderful and perfect, one can hardly believe it was possible to be made at all. But Finding Neverland is one of those movies, sweet, innocent and wonderfully charming, it captures the heart and whisks  it away to a land of fairies, pirates and where children can stay young forever.

J.M Barrie is played by the wonderful Johnny Depp, who is both kind and thoughtful. His innocent childish heart shining in every work he writes and the stories he made up to amuse the brothers Davies, while quietly romancing the mother played by equally wonderful Katie Winslet.

This is a movie that will steal your heart from the opening scene to the heartbreaking last, and I wonder if it is at all possible not to cry at the wonderland Barrie created for Sylvia.

Watch this movie, and let yourself become young again, because after all age is just a state of mind.

Low-key, competent performances by the entire cast in this remarkable film made for a realistic depiction of J.M. Barrie's life and times.

Visually lovely, yet nicely understated, the movie allows the viewer to let their own imagination soar into the Neverland that Barrie created.

You'll be moved, and you'll think about the childhood favorite Peter Pan in a whole new way.

Reviewer: Linda Painchaud-Steinman, Park Edge Books

This film is a true gem. It is a slow and dramatic account of the adult life of James Barrie. It is very sad, beautiful, and shines as one of the best productions of 2004.

It is not a chick flick. It is very neutral, and can be enjoyed immensly by the male and female audience.

See this, you will be impressed.

Rarely does a film portray real life without maudlin sadness or giddy saccharine dialogue. "Finding Neverland" is just what the titles suggests - a `neverland'. J.M. Barrie (a splendidly underplayed Johnny Depp) is a man that escapes his unsatisfying married life by fantasy (he is a playwright). Helping him create his best play happens when he befriends four boys who's Mother is the widow Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (an adorable Kate Winslet). To complicate matters, Sylvia's Mother (Julie Christy at her coldest role yet), intervenes suggesting that a grown man should not be interested in young boys and Sylvia should not be interested in a married man. The friendships develop with a turn of face by every character by the stories end. Freddie Highmore plays a young boy who steals every scene he is in. This is a light-hearted story threatening to be undermined by the stuffy British society who is viewed as the `evil adult world'. Slight scenes of fantasy are cleverly interspersed throughout the film and the epiphany that each character captures is brilliantly scripted. Peter Pan never looked so good.

From what I've heard, I gather they take some liberties with Barrie's life and the controversy around it.  But hey - A Beautiful Mind, Ray ... that's what they do in Hollywood.

Depp continues to prove himself as one of the best ators we have and Kate Winslet is just so, so luminous, she just lights up the screen.  The children are beautifully played, the period captured gorgeously ... it is a real treat to look at.

It is a little slow and, sometimes, a little less whimsical than you might like, but it is a very moving, heartfelt film. We should all hope that we can find Neverland someday.
Nt Very Good At All. And Its Not Interesting. I Doesn`t Make You Want To Learn More About Neverland. Don`t Buy This Movie.

I never liked Johnny Depp much until Pirates of the Caribbean. I don't know why, but his portrayal in that movie cracked me up. He picks his movies carefully, and in the past, he just seemed strange. Kind of like an actor-version of Tim Burton. Now I am beginning to see that he is evolving as an actor, and as he evolves, he becomes better and better.

As someone who existed on myths and fairytales when growing up, because the reality of life being a deaf child in a hearing school (and so constantly tortured...), I was not enamored of Peter Pan as done by Disney. It was insipid stuff, especially for a child with high reading skills at an early age. I much prefered even the musical with Mary Martin, and that thing was quite old by the time I started seeing it regularly on television.

As I grew older, I read a lot more especially in college about Barry. He was not a successful man. He was lonely, and estranged from everyone. Who knows what type of psychological trauma he experienced. But I also read about him and the 'Lost Boys,' and there is no comparison between this man and his relationship with this family and a certain more modern person who will remain unnamed here. Barry learned to care for not just the boys, but this family (the father did not appreciate his presence in the family like the mother did not)...

To an extent Barry was right. None of us want to grow up, because growing up means a lot of hurting...Barry was trying to explain that from the view of a child. I would rather have stayed home with my family who cared about me than going out into the real world, in which deafness is considered a 'horrific' difference. The feelings evoked by my favorite fairytales, whether in book format or movie format, were very much raised in this movie.

the acting is beautiful, by all concerned. Even my husband was solemn at the end of the movie and admitted it was sweetly done. Depp continues to delight and surprise me, though I am aprehensive about his next foray with Burton into Willy Wonka, but I'll hold off judging him again, until I see his work.

this is a beautiful movie...

Karen Sadler

As a kid I never really cared about Peter Pan.  The story was boring to me and I never gave it much thought at all.  I went to see this film because I love Johnny Depp and I must see all of his pictures.  Needless to say I was completely blown away.

"Finding Neverland" is one of those films that is all too rare in American cinema these days.  This movie tells one of the sweetest and most heartful stories I have ever heard.  I am sure certain liberties have been taken with the "trueness" of its tale, but regardless, this film and its story are a pure joy to watch.  The filmmakers struck pure gold.  The set design, direction, and atmosphere of the film are perfect.  They suck the audience into the story and set the tone perfectly.  And the acting.....This is by far my favorite Kate Winslet performance.  It's not her most fun role, or even her most challenging, but I believe it is her most caring and genuine.  The same can be said of Johnny Depp.  As the main "grown-ups" in this film about four boys, it was extremely important that the actors portraying the children's parent (Winslet) and best-friend (Depp) love children and be able to relate to them not as kids, but as people.  That's why I love this movie.  Johnny, Kate, and the entire story treat children as they deserve to be treated: as real, important, awesome people.  This movie is awesome because it respected, nourished, and loved everything that is brilliant about childhood, and the adult actors obviously respected and loved childhood an equal amount.

This is a calming, beautiful, happy story that was snubbed out of its obvious best picture win because the Academy has no use for happy, loving, family films.  This is the kind of movie we need more of.  The kind that puts smiles on faces and calmness in our hearts.  Watch this movie and you'll see what I mean.

How sad, how sad.  With such rich material to mine, the filmmakers come up with such predictable drek...

Mr Depp is completely mis-cast. Mumbles his way through the entire film trying to impress us how good his Edinburgh accent is. It's like watching  Meryl Streep. Neither one of them hold up well as the years go by. This, like so many of hers, sadly, is the performance of an automaton, not a flesh and blood human.

Kate W fares much better - as does the remarkable Ms Christie. All else fails. The children are sweet, and notable in fact, but cartoon characters in the end.

The film suffers greatest at the hands of its 'director' - or directors/producers. All the imagination that could have been summoned up by the VIEWER is hammered home by completely unnecessary special effects and 'dream' sequences.

Terribly disappointing. This is rendered worse than a formula TV movie where Patty Duke gets cancer and is 'helped over'.

The music swells. The tears comes to the children. Mr Depp demurs.

But emptiness ABOUNDS, here. Precisely what Mr barrie would have abhorred.

Johnny Depp is glorious as always and they did the perfect job with this film of keeping everything "just enough." They didn't overexplain anything, beat subtlties into the ground or make me feel like the filmmakers thought I was an idiot, just a simply magical story with the perfect amount of childlike wonder. Oh and the Irish terrorist from Alias was representing as Peter Pan which I appreciated. Great special features as well!

This film is not so much a documentary, but an exploration in the creative process that made J M  Barrie Write PETER PAN.

As such, it looks at visions that creep into the viewpoint of the main character. The Commentary illustrates just how much of the fictional story interplays with the factual story of the life of the real J M Barrie.

From Start to Finish the film works as an enjoyable masterpiece. You will never know what parts are FX and what parts are not FX  unless you see the "Creating Neverland"  bonus feature. In this area, the care and the love for this story is evident in the way the actors, actresses, and producers  approach the film. It is still bizarre as how the deleted scenes  were expunged since the scenes were just great.

Radha Mitchell plays the ice Queen a little too well, and seems to me to be type-cast with her quality persona.

After seeing the film, you will totally enjoy the out-takes, or what some call the Blooper reel.

From start to finish, this film as an amazing product. And the extras are perfectly done.

ENJOY.

As I was reading below, I noticed a little bit of controversy regarding the true events surrounding this story, and the events that took place in the picture itself. Take note that it says "Inspired by True Events" at the start of the film as opposed to Based on a True Story, meaning that the events of the plot are only loosely connected to the actual events that happened in real life.

Forget the true story while watching Finding Neverland, and just appreciate it for the good film that it is. It's not very often that you see a film as inspiring, imaginative, or as moving as this.

I was surprised how much I enjoyed Finding Neverland. I thought the acting and story were wonderful and well played. However after doing some research I see again that Hollywood likes to manipulate the facts. Although its True Barrie had a strong connection with the boys in the story, the true story is far more tradgic. Many would liken Barrie to Micheal Jackson in that his love for children may have bordered on paedophilia (a controvery that has surrounded Barrie for a long time), although the boys all denied it and nothing was every proven.

Tragically one children the oldest, George was killed in WW1, six years later Micheal drowned mysteriously, with his hands were tied to those of his best male Rupert Buxton. Some speculate that the two were gay and commited suicde together, although no one knows for sure.  Peter Davies always resented the character he had inspired and drank himself to poverty and ruin, eventually killing himself by jumping in front of a tube train.

Other controvery surrounds Barrie. One major one that is not noted in the movie is that Barrie himself forged his name into Sylvia Davies will replacing his name Jimmy with the name of Jenny, a sister of the nurse Mary who looked after Sylvia.

When Barrie died in 1937 he cut the two surviving brothers (Jack and Nicholas) from his will.

There is more but find out for yourself if you are interested.....

The more you learn about the truth behind James Barrie the more you see how truely flawed the new movie is. Although don't let this stop you from enjoying it and the story it tells. However out of respect for the real characters involved be sure you understand that this movie is very much fictional and that the real story is far less enchanting, a bit disturbing and truely tragic. However make sure you do your own research and draw your own conclussions!
This movie is excruciatingly slow-moving. The pacing is glacial and not much happens...Even diehard anglophiles will do well to stay away from this stinker.

I loved this movie.... Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet were wonderful....

The only problem that I had with the movie, is that it left me wanting more....

What happened next? Did James Barrie adopt these boys? Did Peter go on to write? Did these boys require years of psycho-therapy to overcome losing both parents to illness in a rather short period of time.... there I go again, babbling on aimlessly......
