The story of Peter Pan is one that is near and dear to my heart. In that sense, I approached "Finding Neverland" with both excitement and fear, because I wondered what would be made with this film.

Was it accurate historically? No, but it was beautifully done. James Barrie was 5'0", a small man who seemingly had a medical issue with adolescence, and in that sense, he never really did grow up. He married, but the marriage was supposedly never consumated. So, he could neither have children, or in his society, stay a child. Although he was a successful playwright, it is not surprising then that he became fascinated with the FIVE (in the movie, four) Davies boys as well as their parents (both were alive, as opposed to the movie.)

The movie wove a new tale - allowing both Depp and Winslet to show the CONCEPTS even if not applying all the facts. The concepts were those of sadness and longing for the things you cannot have, as well as the belief that you CAN have those things, even if only in your mind, or in Neverland - which is a map of the mind, even Barrie says that in Peter Pan.

This concept that your attitude decides your happiness has always touched my heart. My company is named "Second Star Creations" with that in mind. I believe James Barrie did a wonderful job portaying Peter Pan as the boy who would never grow up, and Wendy as the girl/woman wondering if she should.
Finally, I felt this wonderful movie showed similar concepts in portraying the author himself - those of enjoying life, even while being unable to have children of his own, and those of "trying to belong" in a world where he did not fit.

You can indeed - "find Neverland" - in this movie.
Dan T. Davis, author - "The Blacksmith's Gift"

I saw this movie in a small town theater with my girlfriend. Going into it, I expected good things...with the combination of Johnny Depp's acting and a story about fairies and imagination. But I have to admit, this movie blew me away. Rarely have I seen a movie that evokes such emotion without resorting to cheesy, overused one-liners.

There is one point in the story, during a performance of Barrie's play, "Peter Pan," when a character says, "Clap if you believe in fairies." Well I must say, there were a good many people clapping in the audience, both young and old. At the end of the movie, everyone was in or near tears. I was one of them, though not primarily because of sadness; just because the movie was so darn well done.

Many types of people will enjoy this movie - the elderly who remember a more innocent time as well as families who want to experience some quality entertainment together. This is a solid movie all around, and in fact was my favorite new release of 2004.

GothamGirl and another reviewer on here who gave low ratings seem to miss the point of the movie.

To the reviewer who gave a rating of 1 Star, of course there aren't going to be any real pirates in this or a shot gun blast to the chest. This movie has to do with how playwright J.M. Barrie came up with the idea for writing Peter Pan. So it makes perfect sense that there would be kids and grown-ups dressed up as pirates and such in this movie. If you were going into this movie thinking it would be like Depp's last movie Pirate of the Carribean, than you probably shouldn't have gone to see this.

To GothamGirl, yes, the movie can be a bit slow but personally I wouldn't have preferred it any other way than to have the movie focus on Barrie and his wife. It's the estrangement between him and his wife that causes him to form this frienship with four boys and their widow mother. And actually, I felt the movie did a wonderful job of balancing the focus between Barrie and his wife as well as with Winslet's character and her family of four boys.

Now on to the movie, lol. First off definitely gotta say that I loved this movie and will be adding it to my DVD library when it comes out to DVD on March 22. The tear jerkers come more towards the end, but it's still a very touching movie and certainly filled with a lot of magic, imagination and wonder. Depp as always does a great job and I become more and more a fan of his with each movie I see (looking forward to the Burton movie of Charlie And The Chocolate Factory that he's doing and the sequel to Pirates Of The Carribean). Depp's Scottish accent was perfect (at first I thought the accent was Irish since I hadn't realized that Barrie is originally Scottish). Freddy Sizemore is incredible as a boy who demands to grow up as quickly as possible so as not to feel the pain that children feel when losing a loved one like a parent(s). Sizemore was just incredibly talented in this film, which leads me to believe we can expect more great things from him as he gets older not too mention seeing more of his talent as Charlie Bucket in Tim Burton's version of Charlie And The Chocolate Factory.

I definitely recommend this movie for the entire family to watch, but be sure to have some tissues ready.

It is not easy to gripe about a sweetly sentimental film that deals un-mawkishly with a theme as mawkish as this, but if you've seen the recent Ewan McGregor starrer 'Big Fish,' you may find Neverland wanting in luster. But I'm putting the horse before the cart, plus that's not the point.

Several glowing tributes in major publications had me convinced that Neverland was a biopic of JM Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan. In reality the film is not smitten one bit with the misery of historical precision - google for Barrie and you'll see even his looks were a world apart from a very comely Johnny Depp.

It is more a silver-tongued ode to the magic of imagination, to the pursuit of a joy in art that's elusive in the Real World, to the value of retaining a childlike wonder while acquiring a mature understanding of the world.

On all of those levels, it eclipsed my expectations. Even if we were to discount Peter Pan and think of Barrie as just an obscure, failed writer, this heartfelt film would still enchant with equal intensity.

The screenplay glides between full-blown fantasy sequences to reveal the fertility of Barrie's brain while keeping us grounded in reality. If Big Fish and Neverland were put belly to belly, I suspect that the former would have an edge, but Neverland's set up of its context is fluent and fascinating while sporting some old Edwardian restraint.

Johnny Depp is probably one of the finest actors around, I marvel at his ability to find poetry in his character while turning in a measured presence with a very unobstrusive Scottish accent. He even looks about 15 years younger than his real age. I've never seen Kate Winslet as maternal as this but she's luminous nonetheless. An egging romantic subplot is tossed between the two, always platonic on the surface but not without a tinge of intrigue if you pay attention to those prolonged glances.

Hoffman has an embarrasingly marginal role, so if you're expecting some histrionics from him, don't. It is unclear why he's doing this -- Lemony Snicket has a painfully trivial appearance from him too.

The true stars of the show however are the four young boys, especially Freddie Highmore who plays the cynical child to whom "Peter" Pan was dedicated.

There will understandably be some quibbles with this film. Perhaps the scope is too modest -- we barely begin to enjoy Barrie's consummation of his fantasties when all of it comes to an abrupt end. Or perhaps, especially in hindsight, it all feels like we stepped on the sob pedal too hard, which is not helped by some pat dialgue about, gulp, 'believe in it'.

If you come away from this film with such a Scrooge-like perspective, it's ironically a good sign that you need a ticket to Neverland yourself.

It's a well-done, moving film. I enjoyed my time in the theatre. Pack your Kleenex, keep your quixotic horses saddled, and soon, like the audience in the film itself, you'll find yourself wondering if we ever really let go of that child in ourselves. Marvellous film.

I can't argue that Johnny Depp is a brilliant actor.  I've loved him since I first saw Edward Scissorhands, but I  don't think that he was able to act out his full potential in this movie. Most of the movie revolves around the stiff, almost deadpan relationship between him and his wife, so the movie plays a bit slow.  If there had been more scenes with J.M. Barrie and the boys in imaginative situations, I think this movie would have been more of a hit.  The movie didn't start to get really interesting and inspiring until about the last 10 minutes. I was a bit disappointed, because I was looking forward to this movie, but I don't really think it's a must-have for one's dvd library. It's too bad because I really think this movie would have been able to be a classic had it not focused so much on Barrie and his wife.

"Finding Neverland" is a deeply moving, poetic film, based on the life of Scottish playwright and novelist James Matthew Barrie, and adapted from Allan Knee's play "The Man Who Was Peter Pan." It is a fictional account of how Barrie came to write "Peter Pan," which has long been a beloved children's classic symbolizing everlasting youth.

Johnny Depp gives an unusually understated, sensitive performance as J. M. Barrie, who is facing a crisis in life. His latest play is not receiving accolades, and his marriage has grown cold and sterile. He meets Sylvia Llewelyn Davies, (Kate Winslet), a widowed mother of four sons, and immediately hits it off with her boys - played by Joe Prospero, Nicholas Roud, Luke Spill, and the extremely gifted Freddie Highmore as Peter. Although he is friendly with Sylvia, it is with the children that he is able to take-off on glorious flights of imagination. And the five of them soar. Their back-yard games transform into fantasy imagery. They're flying!! The results are remarkable scenes played out as adventures, veritable fetes of daring. He and the boys act as pirates sailing the Spanish Main, cowboys and "red Indians" riding the plains of the old West.

In reality, however, this is Edwardian England, not the Wild West, and Barrie's friend Arthur Conan Doyle, (Ian Hart), warns him of vicious gossip about his "unseemly" interest in the family. Barrie responds with disgust. As he becomes increasingly involved with the boys, tension escalates between him and his upper-class wife, Mary, (Radha Mitchell). Sylvia's mother, Emma (Julie Christie), also lifts a questioning brow, wondering why on earth a grown man would spend so much time with children, and someone else's to boot!

Barrie's deep feelings for Sylvia and her boys are genuine. A decent man, he never had kids of his own, nor did he have much of a childhood. Complex and creative, emotionally immature with a brilliant mind, he carves out a realm for himself with the Davies family, his own Neverland of sorts. He lavishes them with affection, gifts, and tons of energy as he enacts, with them all, his inspired games. His poignant longing for the childhood he missed is evident. For me, Barrie epitomizes the "lost boy." The children, in turn, love him back and gift him with the inspiration for his haunting tale of Peter Pan, the youth who refuses to grow up. In David Magee's screenplay, Sylvia is the female figure in Barrie's fantasies - like a Wendy - more maternal than wifely.

Sorrow and loss lie just over the horizon from this world of fantasy and delight, but I will keep them at bay here. Let it suffice to say that some dark themes are explored. Director Marc Forster has delivered a fine period piece, with amazing sets and costume design. The acting is superb. Johnny Depp imbues the film with a sense of wonder. Ultimately, "Finding Neverland" is about holding on to the all the magical aspects of childhood and keeping the imagination alive. This movie touched me deeply. PS - bring some extra tissues along.

JANA
I just recently saw this film and it blew me away. To me it was one of the most touching and magical films i have ever seen. Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet did an excellent job in this movie.
i went in expecting a great movie and thats exactly what i got

I must admit I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  Good performances by Johnny Depp and the rest of the cast.  Many times when working with child actors it can make or break a film.  I am happy to say it was an asset to this movie.  Solid directon and writing should also be noted here.  The movie had nice pacing and didn't drag much at all.  A great movie suspends the disbelief of the audience. This movie made you feel like you were part of the magic of the making of Peter Pan.  Highly recommended.

This movie is one of the most wonderful I have ever seen. It is terribly hard for movies to make me cry, but by the end of this movie, I felt so connected to the characters that I was in tears. The story is beautiful, the costumes and set are brilliant, and Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet have Oscar-quality performances.

Fair warning: This is easily the most affecting movie I've seen all year.  You know those little packets of Kleenex at the check-out stand? Not going to cut it. Maybe the travel-size box will do. I'm sorry if this review is more vague than usual but I don't want to say too much because, in this instance, anyone who spoils the ending for you is an absolute boor.

'Finding Neverland' explores the relationships in the life J. M. Barrie that inspired his masterwork, 'Peter Pan.' But it goes beyond the mere workings of creativity. It actually becomes a celebration of imagination itself and the day-to-day hope and comfort that can be fashioned by it.

Johnny Depp actually gets out of the way of the character and Kate Winslet does her usual excellent period piece work. Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman have important parts (Even if a bit distracting. I mean just how many women had obvious facelifts in the early 1900s?). But the most impressive actor by far in this picture is then-nine-year-old Freddie Highmore as Winslet's son, Peter. He brings immediacy and honesty to a role that the movie hinges upon and will probably leave the most lasting impression on viewers.

Though the film has its flaws and a few "misunderstood artist" cliches, its vision eventually rises effortlessly above them, much like the Darling children when they also think of a wonderful thought.

The penultimate scene is beyond description. On paper it would sound awfully simple. But the thoughtfulness, joy, longing, and healing in that one elegant, emotionally explosive moment is one of the most powerful and profound that I've ever experienced.

I don't hand out praise like that very often. But 'Finding Neverland' earned it.

This is Johnny Depp at his best. I loved his wide-eyed innocence throughout the movie, from when he's peeking through a curtain to see the audience's reactions during one of his plays to when he's dressing up as pirates or indians to please the boys.

Another exceptional actor is Freddie Highmore, playing Peter, who does an excellent job portraying the anger and confusion in his character.

I think you need to have watched an early version of Peter Pan to understand the inside jokes of Finding Neverland, which I'm sure will cause a few snickers and some feelings of deja vu.

A lot of people told me this movie reminded them of their inner child, or the child they used to be. To me, this movie shows  how inncoent and fun life can be when you just look through the eyes of a child.

I thought this was an incredible movie--moving, comical, tragic,romantic maybe, all rolled into one. Definitely a film for adults and children alike. I saw it the day the Oscar nominations came out (although I had intended to see it before)and I was blown away! Johnny Depp was incredible, Kate Winslet wonderful and the children were amazing. This is my idea of a Best PIcture in the fashion of Old Hollywood--a film with an ongoing and timeless message. It is a movie that makes one stop and look at what is really important in a world of cell phones, 50 inch TV's and all the crass materialism of today's world. I am a huge fan of the Victorian era so this film was right up my alley but the message of the film spoke to my soul in such a way that mere words cannot describe it. I boo-hooed my heart out (along with the other 12 people in the theater that day). This is an ageless film that EVERYONE should see and pay attention to the core theme of following and listening to your heart and keeping the child in you alive.

This is an awesome film.  Sweet but not sickening, and sad.

Just make sure you have lots and lots of kleenex.

J.M. Barrie would have been proud of the filmmakers of Finding Neverland. Not only does the cast do an outstanding job, but director Marc Forster expertly directs this movie with strength.

The two best performences were Johnny Depp and Freddy Highmore. Johnny Depp never makes me say "He's so bad!". But Mr. Highmore is going to make it in Tinseltown. He gave a wonderful performence in Two Brothers, and now I can't wait for Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Awesome movie.

"Finding Neverland" is one of the best Johnny Depp films, behind "Secret Window" and "Pirates of the Caribbean." Kate Winslett also stars in this magnificant film that tells everyone you are not too old to act like a child.

Mr. Barrie's (Johnny Depp) play, Peter Pan, was so ground-breaking, so unusual, that even his producer (Dustin Hoffman) thought him a bit cuckoo when he presented his ideas to him. And with the miserable failure of his last play, it's little surprise.

But this new one has something unusual, something not quite tangible in the mind. Why? Because Mr. Barrie's inspiration was a group of young boys who've lost their father and are preparing for the worst kind of news about their mother, too (played excellently by Kate Winslet).

What struck me as interesting and incredible about the film is that it focuses on the muse of a writer; and this muse is pretty dark. Peter (Freddie Highmore), is a lonely boy even within his family of brothers. He misses his father terribly, and he doesn't know how to grieve. So when Johnny Depp appears in his life, he's none too happy about it ("You can't replace my father"). Can this young boy find salvation in the writings of one man? Can he find that bit of serendipity that we all lose as children when we hit the barrier of adulthood? Even with his mother in mortal danger?

Sound kinda dark? It is. But the amazing thing about it is that the film is tremendously uplifting, even with death looming in the shadows.

I will say that Johnny Depp never ceases to amaze me. I loved him in Pirates of the Caribbean, and it was often times difficult for me to imagine that this was the same actor playing this role. Kate Winslet was excellent as the ailing mother. Julie Christie was wonderful as the protective grandmother of Winslet's children. But to me, the show stealer was undoubtedly Freddie Highmore (Peter). I don't know where this boy came from, but his presence on screen brought a lump to my throat from the moment I saw him, and by the end of the film everyone in the theater (I mean everyone!) was blubbering like a baby. A shame that he didn't get nominated for Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars.

I'll be owning this one on DVD when it comes out.

At the beginning of "Finding Neverland", struggling playwright J.M. Barrie (Depp) is in a rut, as he has been creating uninspiring and boring plays. The film suggests he tried to write to his audience, rather than remaining true to his own worldview and letting everyone see his unique form of genius. Barrie discovers the secret to unlocking his brilliance when he develops a deep platonic love for a widow and her four young boys and draws on them as his muse. From his time with the fatherless family, the world is given the play "Peter Pan".

Although Barrie develops a powerful and strangely non-sexual love for the mother of the boys (Kate Winslet), it is his relationship with her children that touches his heart and opens a path toward emotions he has repressed for years. Seeing the innocence in them reminds Barrie of a simpler time in his life when dreams came true and magic lurked around every corner.

He immerses himself in their lives, inventing imagination outlets for the boys and driving them to believe in dreams and wonder. What Barrie feels for the children is hard to explain (and in today's time would be viewed with a few raised eyebrows). He develops the kind of pure, unconditional love that convinces others it must be tainted in some way. No man can love a stranger's four boys so much.

Like "Shakespeare in Love", the audience gets to see how real life events become iconic moments from literature. The film's lasting images include beautiful dissolves from reality to imagination, as Barrie's mind alters and sculpts experiences to fit his play. One unforgettable image begins with the four boys jumping on their beds and (in Barrie's mind) becomes the famous scene from "Peter Pan" where the children float out of their bedroom.

While the film makes important declarations as to the power of wide-eyed youthful imagination and challenges viewers to recapture the wonder of childhood, it at times becomes laborious to watch. The only real conflict in the film is painfully artificial and clichd (disapproval from Barrie's wife and the boys' grandmother). Indeed, it is an inspirational and magical film, but it just seems to be lacking a little something extra to make it great.

I took my children to see Finding Neverland yesterday and today I can't wait for it to be released on Video.

I expected Johnny Depp to be wonderul (he is), Kate Winslet to be beautiful and fabulous (she is) and the story to be winning (it is).  But I don't think I expected to be as moved by this beautiful story as I was.  There's just something about it--an aching beauty, I think I'd call it--that epitomizes the poignancy of childhood, love, and the human ability to dream that almost goes beyond the power of words to describe it.  It walks the edge of the precipice of innocence/experience in a watercolor balancing act that is as delicate and yet as durable and neverending as the circle of life itself.  I fell in love with every aspect.

Here's a scary revelation for you:  Evan "Average Joe Reviewer" Hinton is actually agreeing with the snooty movie critic community on one of those serious Oscar-worthy pictures.  Yes, usually I find the deep, emotional, dramatic films boring and dull; but, except for a minor bout of yawn-induction, "Finding Neverland" is an interesting and touching drama starring one of Hollywood's current superstars: Johnny Depp.

 "Finding Neverland" is the (almost) entirely true story of how English playwright James Matthew Barrie was inspired to write his most famous play:  "Peter Pan".  Interestingly enough, it was originally scheduled to premiere last year, which would have been about the same time as the latest movie rendition of Barrie's famous play hit theaters.  Ultimately, "Peter Pan" didn't pan out (har!) too well, but at the time Columbia Pictures refused to allow Miramax to use portions of the play if the movies were released at the same time, so the film was held for a year.  "Finding Neverland" premiered in the larger cities months ago, but has recently gotten a lot of Oscar buzz, so our humble theater has begun showing it here.

 As the story goes, J. M. Barrie (Johnny Depp) was inspired to create a story of children who didn't grow up by the Llewelyn Davies boys: George (Nick Roud), Jack (Joe Prospero), Michael (Luke Spill), and most significantly, Peter (Freddie Highmore).  He meets them in the park one day, and they become good friends and playmates.  Barrie uses his incredible imagination to entertain and enlighten the boys, all the while growing closer to their widowed mother, Sylvia (Kate Winslet).  Unfortunately, some of their romance stuff is pretty slow, and rather predictable, which weighs down the film and prevents it from getting a perfect rating.

 This film is a bit like "Big Fish", with scenes of "reality" intercut with beautiful fantasy.  It's also reminiscent of "Shakespeare in Love", with moments in Barrie's life that obviously inspire aspects of the "Peter Pan" story.

 Even though it is probably technically a "romance", "Finding Neverland" is an interesting tale of how a lasting work of theatrical and literary art is developed and created.  Writers definitely "write what they know".  This film gives us a glimpse at what the inside of a truly creative person's mind must look like:  images and feelings, wrapped together to form a seamless, wonderful tale.

 Johnny Depp is excellent as J. M. Barrie.  His English accent is impeccable, and a different dialect than we heard in "Pirates of the Caribbean" (though he does slip briefly back into Jack Sparrow when he's playing "pirates" with the boys).

 Perhaps what says the most about Depp's skills as an actor is that his next role will be that of zany Willie Wonka in the upcoming remake of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", a abrupt departure from his sophisticated (but still good-humored) J. M. Barrie.
I was very touched by this film. It is much deeper than I imagined while viewing it. The images still remain with me. I think this is a great film because it touches the human heart and soul.

This movie, in every shape and form, is brillant. It has some of the best acting by Kate Winslet and Johnny Depp. It has some great direction by Marc Foster. It has a interesting premise and has a great screen play. It is one of the most brillant films of 2004(and one of the best too.)

The story of Peter Pan is a classic. It is about a boy that never grows up and has fun all the time and never takes on the responsiblities of a adult. He justs lofts around and has fun. J.M. Barie is a struggling playwright, his latest play has bored audiences to sleep. then J.M. Barie starts playing around with a woman and her children,and he draws insperation from those escapades for Peter Pan. But what he doesn't know that They end up becoming attached to each other, and it reaches a emotional peak. The play does well with both adults and children, but the woman that J.M. Barie loves is too ill to see it, so he brings it to her, and in one last beautiful moment with her, shows her Neverland.

The film is, like I said, Brillant. I was in tears by the end of the movie, and I felt for all the characters. Give Johnny Depp the OSCAR!(Jamie Foxx too!). I think the Best Actor should be a tie. This film was great.

Having Johnny Depp protray the beloved author, James Barrie, was just pure genius.  Although, after I learned more truth about Barrie's life, I was a little discouraged about the story. However, I can honestly say that I can look past that, especially with the brilliant acting that Depp brought to the movie. When you're watching the movie you are not seeing Johnny Depp, you're watching John Barrie. That's how good he is.

While I was watching I don't think that I once thought 'I wonder how they did this.' The ensemble cast is brilliant. Kate Winslet as Sylvia Llewelyn Davies was a great choice and wonderful to watch alongside Depp. Her role is very real and moving. The little boys also did a fantastic job acting with their bigger-than-life a-list actors. Dustin Hoffman was Barrie's play director and friend, Charles Frohman.  He had some wonderful lines and was great to watch on screen.

Despite the fact that it's a heart-filled and rather sad movie, I say, 'Go for it,' and watch this film. It'll really make you want to believe in magic again and the dreams of a child.

I am not a Johnny Depp fan. Actually I don't like him at all as an actor or as a person. However, I am not blind to his obvious talent and in this movie, Finding Neverland, I found Depp's performance to be quite excellent. I spend most of the movie waiting for him to give one of his "quirky" performance that would make a mockery of the character he was playing but much to my surprised, Depp managed to remain true to form of a proper Edwardian gentleman. The movie rest much on Depp's and his relationship with the boys. I am happy to report that there seem to be excellent chemistry between the two sides which really made this movie enchanting. Kate Winslet plays the mother of the boys and her role remains somewhat limited as her relationship with Depp remains very platonic.

The movie proves to be very well crafted, produced and there is a nice script to go with it. Thanks to the word "inspired" instead of "based" on real events, the movie can take liberty to the real story and make it work Hollywood style. Depp was well supported by his fellow cast members including Dustin Hoffman who ironically plays Barrie's producer.

Story of how Barrie wrote Peter Pan and how he got his inspiration from the boys remains the central theme to this movie. Its entertaining, fun and heart-warming performances by all players do make this movie a quality film to see for almost anyone.

I spotted only two major weaknesses in this film. First was the ending, it looked like they borrowed it completely from the Anthony Hopkins' movie, Shadowland, even down the last scene where man and boy having a good cry on the bench. Second was that we never got to know the man, J.M. Barrie, even fictionally. The movie seem to be about how Peter Pan was written up, not about the man who wrote it.

But overall, an excellent and fun movie to watch. Its almost sad to note that in real life, the some of the boys had a short tragic life (one drown in Oxford, one got killed in World War I and other - Peter - committed suicide in 1960).

Finding Neverland is inspiring, captivating, bittersweet and heartwarming. Coming up with a classic like Peter Pan has got to be a process of wonder and endless imagination, which is exactly what this film's all about. Superb acting and breathtaking photography make it a big contender at both the box office and award shows. It's definitely one of the best films ever made.

Go see it. It's a great film for the whole family. It's a much needed film in these dark, cold times we live in.

Very highly recommended.

At a time when there are so many films, that after watching you wonder, why was this made.....Finding Neverland was a gem!  Long after you finished watching this film, it had a way of "sticking with you". The acting was wonderful, the story well written.  Rather than the common insult to the intelligence, that our country accepts happily, this film assumes that the viewer is thinking. Loved it!

Haven't there been enough movies on Peter Pan? Geeze! That's exactly what i thought when this first came out, and though i didn't want to admit it, it still looked good. What's so special about this is the beauty about this film. IT's simple and moving, yet still necessary to see. It's necessary because haven't you ever wondered the mind behind the classic book, and inspired movie. I can't even remember a book having so many movies made about it, with the exception of Frankenstein.

  Anyways this movie is lovely. It is sad, and real, and a biography we should all see. The young actors, especially 'Peter' acts quite well, and as always Depp makes another amazing performance, this time in a quiet way. I love Depp, and the roles he picks. They are always creative, and original.

this was a very very good movie. the wife and i went yesterday afternoon to see this great movie. i have always liked johnny depp in what ever he played in. this is a great story of friendship one of the most touching i have ever seen. the little boys in this movie were all great but freddie highmore is one the best little actors i have ever seen. this movie will touch your heart  and break it. i was setting 3 or 4 times with a tear rolling down my face but this show had such a ending the wife and i both had a river of tears flowing down our faces. this is a great date movie guys don't be afraid to take wife or girlfriend to see it and open up your heart and mind when you do you will have a great time of crying and laughing together like the wife and i did.

WONDERFUL! thats the word that comes to mind when i think of this movie. i'm not going to give anything away-watch and find out! but by the end there wasn't a dry eye in the cinerma, kate winslet and the boy who played peter did a fantastic job.

MOVIE: The story of the real Peter Pan, James Mathew Barrie.  The movie opens with Barrie impatiently waiting for reaction on his latest play, he is off to the side watching people's reactions.  At the end it  turns out to be a failure, and his producer who is played by Dustin Hoffman is beginning to become impatient with him.  As Barrie spends one of his afternoons at the park he meets a widowed mother and her four sons. He becomes inspired by the children's soaring minds and imagination and befriends them. However one of the boys, Peter, looks at everything at a literal level.  He still is hanging over the fact that his father died, and playing pretend doesn't seem to cover up reality. The audience sees that Barrie himself is still a child as he teaches the boys to open their minds through various adventures. He ends up spending day after day with the family and becomes close to the mother, played by Kate Winslet.  The grandmother of the family does not approve of Barrie spending all this time with them, and neither does Barrie's wife or the rest of the city.  Sexuality is played around as one of the themes.  Most of the folk feel that  spending time with these children is showing sexual intrest. His wife feels that he is doing this just for Mrs. Davies (Winslet). The audience sees this separation between Barrie and his wife, and she comes across more as his mother than his companion.  They even sleep in seperate rooms.  That is just a small theme addressed, but the major idea of the film is holding on to what you cherish.  Barrie, while although very smart, grows up with these children in a sense.  He is placed into a new role, and as he meets the children he could fit as their sibling, but as time progresses he fits a more fatherly role to them.  The ending will tug at your heart, and while it is tragic it sends the message that no matter what life delivers you, everything you hold dear will stay in Neverland.  All you have to do is close your eyes and you can revisit everything you cherish at anytime.

ACTING/DIRECTING: This year's Best Actor category is tough, and Johnny Depp has a very good chance of taking it.  This is truly the best work he has ever done.  His portrayal of Barrie is poignant and heartfelt.  Marc Foster's visual style of Barrie's imagination is truly vivid and wonderful.  The audience takes a step through the doorway into the mind of a fascinating writer.  The cinematography was also some of the most captivating I've seen in a while.

BOTTOM LINE: Touching, funny, tragic, and heartfelt.  Finding Neverland is an amazing story of finding one's self and finding the things that make us happy and complete.  While sometimes in our lives we may lose the things that complete us, mentally we will always be attached, never letting them escape our thoughts.  Take the opportunity to see Finding Neverland in theaters before the big night.  Most of the major nominees are being re-released due to Oscar publicity, and this one shouldn't be missed.

Finding Neverland is a movie that will warm your heart, bring a tear to your eye and leave you glad you went to see it.  I was sceptical when I went but left very satisfied.  Although I have yet to see every top movie nominated for GGs or AAs this year this one would rank as the best so far.

I absolutely love this movie.  Finding Neverland brings the best out of Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet.  This is one of those movies that at times made me laugh, and towards the end made me cry.  I truly believe that this movie and its actor are oscar worthy.  I can't wait to see it again - and i deffinately recomend it to anyone and everyone!

The story of how JM Barrie came to write the children's classic Peter Pan certainly did alter a few facts, but movie adaptions just have to do it for excitement. Despite his sometimes halting British accent, the dashing Johnny Depp does come across as convincing as the playwright. Often pensive, his world brightens up when he meets the widow Slyvia Davies (Kate Winslet) and her 4 children.

Locked in a loveless marriage and facing a writer's block, Depp's character begins to enjoy many moments with the family and is especially charmed by the little boy called Peter. That brings out the child in Barrie who becomes inspiredto base his new play Peter Pan on this family and their summer spent togther. Kate Winslet is consummate as the just widowed Slyvia, trying to keep the fmaily together while hiding her deteiorating condition from everyone else. The chemistry between the two lead actors is flawless though the screenplay does lean towards suggesting that there is more than just a platonic relationship between the two.

As usual, Julie Christie lends great support as the tyrannical but protective mother to Kate Winslet's Slyvia. And of course, the movie wouldn't work without the innocent charms of the little boy who played Peter, Freddie Highmore. He wears an expression that already shows much of a grown-up in the body of a child with that soulful eye that speaks.

Be prepared for the whimsical finale where a dying Slyvia visits Neverland. Get ready for the Kleenex moment.

PETER PAN was never my favorite childhood story. It has come to life in a number of versions on stage and screen, but the story of the boy who never wanted to grow up never appealed to me. Who knows, maybe I need to release my inner child and that is why I react negatively to it. Since I am not the greatest PETER PAN fan, I had no string desire to see FINDING NEVERLAND. I read reviews in the paper, some of which lauded the work, others which gave it less than favorable grades. It was not until a woman in a writing workshop I attended praised the film that my interest was peaked. She said it was something all writers would relate to and it was well done. Since she, like many of the participants of the workshop could tell an interesting story and appreciate a good story as well, I decided I should go see it. I put it off until after it was nominated for various Academy Awards and decided I had to see it before the Oscars.

I will not say that FINDING NEVERLAND deserves to receive all of the Oscars that it is the running for, but it does deserve all of the nominations it has received. It is a beautiful film with a riveting story. It tells the story of the writer J.M. Barrie and the relationship he has with the widow Sylvia Llewellyn Davies and her four young sons.  Barrie is in an unhappy marriage and his friendship with Sylvia, as well as his fascination with her sons brings him out of a slump. The relationship resulted in his writing the play PETER PAN. The main focus of the film is the relationship between Barrie, Sylvia, and her sons. Little attention is paid to the marital conflict, nor is undue attention paid to the rumors regarding the friendship of Sylvia and Barrie (e.g. Is it Platonic? Why is he so mesmerized by the boys?). Both situations are mentioned so the viewer is aware that Barrie's world is not Neverland. While some could se this as a glossing over of the conflict in the film, the brief attention speaks powerfully and allows the viewer to be aware of the whole situation, which in turn allows the viewer to see how this family inspired what many consider to be a great work by a genius.

The acting is superb. Once again Johnny Depp shows he is a great character actor and Kate Winslet is wonderful as Sylvia. Rahda Mitchell plays Mary Barrie, J.M.'s wife with great skill. She is neither a vixen nor a shrew, which makes the marital difficulties easy to believe. Two of Hollywood's greats, Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman, play supporting roles which are integral to the success of the film. Hoffman is the theatre owner Charles Frohman who produces Barrie's plays and has misgivings about PETER PAN. Julie Christie plays Sylvia's mother Emma du Maurier. Emma is a socialite who appears to be snobby, but we see as the film progresses that it is out of concern for her daughter and grandchildren. Perhaps the characters who have the most emotional pull in the film are the Llewelyn Davies boys George, Jack, Peter, and Michael played by Nick Roud, Joe Prospero, Freddie Highmore, and Luke Spill respectively. While Highmore's Peter is endearing, viewers' hearts go out to Roud's George, who cannot be a Peter Pan like figure when his mother is dying. The setting for the film is beautiful. Early twentieth century England comes to life in a realistic manner, and the props and stage equipment in the theatre are also accurate for the time period. The music is moving and adds an emotional element to the film.

So will it get Best Picture? Maybe, but the competition is steep. I would not expect to see Depp receive best actor in place of Jamie Foxx as Ray Charles, though in another year Depp would be a contender for the award. It could easily win awards for art direction, music, adapted screenplay and costume design. If there was an Academy Award for moving the heart, FINDING NEVERLAND would easily win.

Enjoy!!!

Johnny Depp (Ed Wood, Fear and Loathing In Las Vegas) plays Peter Pan author Sir James Matthew Barrie who puts on plays but never sits threw them. He soon starts to write a familiar story inspired by a a family, a wife, Sylvia Davies, Kate Winslet (Jude, Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind) and her boys. He soon becomes a part of their life making them work their minds of imagination. He has a wife, Radha Mitchell (Pitch Black, High Art), who cant take the pressure of him not being home because he is out visiting Winslet and her boys or he is out walking and written his story. He soon creates this phenomenon, Peter Pan and it is considered his greatest achievement. Also starring Dustin Hoffman (American Buffalo, Runaway Jury), Kelly MacDonald (Entropy, Trainspotting), Julie Christie and Ian Hart (Enemy Of The State, Monument Ave). Depp proves again he is a master at what he does and he should win lots of awards after this. He even channels some of Jack Sparrow in the pirate ship scene and he has a cool irish accent. One of the best movies of the year...wonderful and we know, there's a lot of movies being thrown at us about Peter Pan but I was impressed by this movie, but this is only about him and him writing it, its not actually Peter Pan. Depp fans won't be disappointed because I surely wasnt.

When it comes to The Academy Awards, I would be hard-pressed to find a more deserving movie for as many awards as Finding Neverland.  Adapted Screenplay (from the original play), Costume Design, Original Music Score, Best Picture, and Best Actor are all potential winning categories for this gem of a movie (although I do like Sideways for Best Picture and Jamie Foxx for Best Actor, however).

I vehemently feel that Kate Winslet was slighted by The Academy Awards after not being nominated for her amazingly mesmerizing performance as the widowed Sylvia Llewelyn Davies.  She was, in my opinion, even better than she was in her nominated role from Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.  In any event, Finding Neverland is anything but devoid of sublime acting from all involved.  Depp is equally impressive as enigmatic playwright J.M. Barrie.  All in all, one of the year's best -- period.

Johnny Depp, dead cert for Oscar nomination of 2005, plays J. M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan.  'Finding Neverland' is largely based on the real-life events surrounding the man and the four boys and a widow who inspired the writer to give birth to one of the world's most beloved character, and how the friendship between them gave the magical inspiration to the writer.  And the film has that magical quality too.

After the critical disaster of the stage production (which was also a financial disaster to his patron Charles Frohman played by Dustin Hoffman) J. M. Barrie meets the boys and their mother in the park while walking his dog.  The widowed lady is Sylvia Davies (equally superb Kate Winslet), to whom Barrie is attracted despite the existence of his neglected wife Mary (Radha Mitchell).  In this curious but still interesting way, the magical creation of Peter Pan started.

While Barrie comes to be an unofficial member of Sylvia's family, we realize that there is too much innocence on the side of Barrie, who can see that imagination is a great thing when playing with the kids yelling like pirates in the garden, but who cannot see that he (and Sylvia) is violating the social mores of English middle-class.  Nor can he understand the broken heart of his own wife.

The film takes great liberty with the biographical facts, so don't believe that eveything depicted here is historically accurate.  The story is too neat, with the events compressed within 100 minutes.  And some characters -- such as Ian Hart as Conan Doyle or Julie Christie as Mrs. Emma DuMaurier -- should be given more substantial or complex roles.

But Johhny Depp gives accomplished portrait as Barrie who refused to see certain things in life, and created the character who refuses to grow up, with very warm and tender touch.  Frankly, I find his Scottish accent slightly annoying, and Barrie's naivete that could be more harmful to the Sylvia's family is toned down to make his personality and the film itself more accessable.  He loves Sylvia, it is certain, but not in the way that reminds you of the idea of infidelty.

However, the fine acting from Depp and Winslet overcomes these  strangely vague points, which could be fatally damaging in the hands of other lesser actors.  As it is, the film remains very engaging throughout, as the heart-felt portraits of the people who needed each other to survive the pains that life can give.

Johnny Depp, a beautiful man, plays the reputedly gay author of Peter Pan, J.M. Barrie, in a story of how his love for four boys engendered the famous tale.  While one may quibble about the appropriateness of a line or two, the telling of how Peter Pan came to be is not only magnificent and near flawless, but without doubt one of the more courageous tales of modern cinema, particularly in the way that Depp's performance, devoid of sentimentality, coupled with a subtle script, leaves no doubt neither for the depth of his feeling for the boys nor its integrity.

Johnny Depp plays James Berrie, a playwright who is dealing with an unstable career and a strained marriage.  While writing in the park one day, he befriends Sylvia, a young widow (Kate Winslet), and her four boys. As he begins spending time with the Davies family, James is finally allowed to let his imagination take off, and he is inspired to write the play "Peter Pan."

This is much more than a story about "Peter Pan" itself.  The film focuses on the relationships that James develops with the Berrie children, especially young Peter (played by the adorable Freddie Highmore).  Although his bond with the Davies family is exactly what James needs to get his creative juices flowing, his already strained relationship with his wife Mary (Radha Mitchell) suffers even more because of it.  There is also the issue of Sylvia's mother (Julie Christie), who disapproves with James' relationship with her daughter because she fears it will ruin any chance Sylvia has of remarrying.

The cast of "Finding Neverland" is excellent.  Depp and Winslet deliver exceptional performances as always, and I was especially impressed by the talent of the four young boys in the film.  They all have very promising careers ahead of them.

I think everyone will enjoy this movie.  It's magical and a tad bitersweet, and I left the theatre wanting to learn more about the real James Berrie, as this film is based on his real life.

Johnny Depp is very believable in this film as J.M. Barrie.  The combination of period costume and computer graphics to capture the magic of "Neverland" as it fills Barrie's and the adopted family's imagination is near brilliant.

Kate Winslett and the boy who plays Peter turn in excellent performances.

This story tells how J.M. Barrie created the now-world famous legend of Peter Pan. He (played in this movie by Johnny Depp) befriended a fatherless family while experiencing professional and personal difficulties. Even his own wife (Radha Mitchell) is drawing away from him.

In the staid Victorian world, this frienship subsequently raises some eyebrows; suspicion is immediately upon the two adults. The grandmother is concerned that no man who actually wants to re-marry her daughter will do so with Barrie hanging around, she is really 'tainted' now because of her friendship with a man outside the bonds of marriage.

Barrie however is more interested in learning to see the world from the kid's perspective. He does not appear interested in tainting anybody.

Being shown Neverland---and its's wonders---essentially rejuvinates Barrie into the world-famous author who we know today. There are very subtle allusions to Barrie's improper interest in the boys, but this is not discernable to many viewers; the focus of the screen play appropriately is on how Barrie comes to create Peter Pan.

I did not like her in Titanic, but I honestly loved Kate Winslet in this movie. Her acting was so good that I forgot it was her in the screen play. Ditto for Johnny Depp whom I grew up watching on 21 Jump Street.  I want to see this movie again!

I have so much to say about this movie!  It deserves so much more credit than it has been given!  I loved it!  I loved the imagination factor, I love the actors/actresses, I loved everything.  This movie has to be one of the best movies I have seen in a while.  It came along when I have been disappointed by many movies I have seen recently and this was just great and made me excited that finally there was a movie worth my time!  Go and see this movie--I think you will be happy you did so.

Johnny Depp's performance in this film is nothing short of perfect-not overdone, not underdone-I truely believe that this role for Johnny is oscar caliber and the film also should get some recognition.

 The story is beautifuly done with great performances by everyone involved. Do yourself a favor and treat your and your loved ones to this amazing true story of one man's vision to create one of the most well known fairy tale's of all time.

I LOVED this movie!!!  I wasn't sure how much longer it would be playing so I went last night to see it and what a treat it was!  The story is, of course, how Peter Pan came to be.  And though there may be some historical inaccuracies in the name of art, the story, acting and pretty much everything about this film is perfectly done.  Johnny Depp, who charmed his way into everyone's heart with his wickedly funny portrayal of Capt Jack Sparrow in the surprise hit, "Pirates of the Carribean", will no doubt win more hearts with this role. He is thoroughly charming as J. M. Barrie, a writer suffering from a couple of back to back flops in the theater world.  As fate would have it, he is out one day in the park and comes across a group of boys with their mother (the beautiful and talented Kate Winslet).  These boys steal Barrie's heart, especially the stoic Peter, who seems to be drowning in grief over the loss of his father.  In no time, he becomes "Uncle James" and spends more time with the boys and their Mom than he does at home.  This doesn't help his already suffering marriage; his wife has all been given up on the marriage by this time but ultimately gives the writer an ultimatum---her or the work.

Depp's performance is extremely good and shows how he just gets better and better.  I would love to see him get an Academy Award nomination for this role.  Ms. Winslet is, as usual, perfect in her role as the adoring mom.  She too deserves a nomination though many feel if she gets a nod it will be for her earlier film, "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind".  And though I doubt it will happen, it would be nice to see the young boy who played Peter get a supporting nod.

Regardless of winning awards or not, this is my favorite film that was released in 2004.  Run, fly, swim----do whatever you have to do to get to the theater to see this heart warming film.  I'm already awaiting the dvd release...I'll be one of the first ones in line for this little treasure.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

This is the best movie that I have seen in probably about 6 months.  Now I know what you are thinking "Johnny Deep playing the guy who wrote Peter Pan?  If can never work".  That is exactly what I thought until I saw the movie for myself.  The performances by all are excellent and at the end of the day the movie will leave you with a warm feeling, even if you are confused as to how the various elements of the movie combined to give you that warm feeling.

Its not just got elements of comedy there is also a fair amount of drama and something of a love story in here as well.  Several important life lessons are learned as such as how we all deal with grief individually.  Obviously some liberties were taken with the actual events as they occurred but the movie manages to sprinkle in the Hollywood elements without insulting the audience.  Please give it a chance.

Overall-10/10

Ever since I was a little girl, Peter Pan has been my absolute favorite literary character, and now, as an aspiring writer (especially in the children's genre), I have begun to truly admire J.M. Barrie's work in a completely different way.  I went into this film with very high expectations, both for the story and for the performances of two of my favorite actors, Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet.  I was in no way disappointed.  Depp's performance was, as Peter would say in the film, "magical."  He gave Mr. Barrie a childlike quality that made his creation of the character of Peter Pan inevitable.  Winslet, as usual, evoked so much emotion with just a look that it was no use for me to try not to cry.  I never thought that the story got overly sentimental, Depp and the children gave too many laughs in their performances to allow that.  I was also fascinated by the looks into Barrie's imagination throughout the film.  This not only provided some wonderfully striking images, but it lent itself perfectly to the creation of Peter Pan and his Neverland.  Overall, this was a beautiful film with stellar performances by both Kate Winslet and Johnny Depp.  I recommend this to any child, aged 0-99.

I was surprised how much I loved it. It was a very subtle film, yet the quietness of it is what I found appealing. It was directed with a sense of what I could imagine how Barrie viewed things in his life. Visually the movie is very beautiful with top-notch production.  Moreover, I'm glad the director avoided being too sentimental with the material. Instead, the movie develops with emotional scenes that carry real value in the characters and the audience. This is definitely one of the best pictures I've seen recently (if not the best of the year). I also have to applaud Johnny Depp, giving a quiet performance that was very wonderful. I'm hoping it does well with the Academy Awards (a nomination for "Best Picture" with recognition towards director Marc Forster, and actor Johnny Depp). It's a visually treat and satisfies. I will not hesitate to buy it when it is released on DVD.

but I can't.  It's that simple.  The movie is absolutely fantastic.  You'll laugh, cry, and remember your youth from long ago.  It's completely clean and completely innocent, very well-acted, and a complete joy to watch.  I LOVED this movie.

Finding Neverland is the story about how Sir James Barrie inspired by a widowed family and wrote the all time classics Peter Pan.

James (Johnny Depp) was having a serious writer block and his last work flopped badly. He was in need of inspiration and his marriage was on the rocks. Fate brought him to meet the widowed family of Sylvia Davies (Kate Winslet), whose deceased husband left her 4 boys on her own. Through interactions with the boys, each having their own character, James weaved together a masterpiece that originally was thought of insane, but then turned to be the classic that everyone now still reads and enjoys.

Johnny Depp gave a spectacular performance again as James Barrie. Not that he put on an accent for the role, but the way he re-created James Barrie as a living character again. The struggle he exhibited for his career, the way how he wanted to solve the marriage problem and yet tried to avoid it, the straight innocence and purity for his care of the boys, and his crazy and imaginative way of telling his stories. Johnny Depp handled every single aspect of the character with a magic touch and yet you could see any side of his character fell apart from the main body. The scenes in which he told Sylvia his childhood secret. and the last scene with Peter were just so well done that you just got drawn into the world of James Barrie and felt that you were there.

Kate Winslet as Syvia Davies gave a good turn of her character choice compared to her other movies. She re-lived the life of a woman who contributed her life for her 4 sons. She was worn out by life, she was living through grief, and yet she still wanted to believe that imagination could be solution to problems. You could feel her pain inside her glances from time to time. The character choice was great.

The supporting cast was also great. Nick Roud who played George and Freddie Highmore who played Peter were two of the more outstanding ones in terms of performance opportunities. Both were boys who were forced to grow up because of the mishappening at home, but deep inside they wish they could still live a life as a boy of their parents. They are the muse for James and thus eventually named the main character in his play after Peter.

Finding Neverland is about the retention of childhood, imagination and creativity in the grown up world. It is the desire to remind the audience about, what matters inside your mind and make believe is the energy of life, no matter what the situation is. This is why James Barrie reserved seats for a group of kids on the opening night, despite the opposition of the theatre manager. It was only through the laughter of the kids that, the audience felt relax and could actually enjoy the imagination and creativity provided by the Neverland.

The movie itself has quite a bit of sad elements in it, however, because of what we saw the characters were trying to do, even after weeping (yeah you could hear people weeping in the cinema) you would still feel very good about the movie. The subtle positive energy delivered by the movie would make you to remember it, feel it and appreciate it. The soundtrack accompanying the movie is also marvellous. The tune just fit perfectly into the world of the movie and helped carry the emotion to the audience vividly.

Finding Neverland could easily be one of the best movies of the year, without shedding blood, cutting limbs, or any 100 million dollar special effect. In fact, just looking at how older day's theatre tried to expand their imagination on their stage design is already a pleasure. It is not a moving to be missed during this post holiday season.

I went to the theatres with my friend to see Finding Neverland and expected a sappy drama. It turned out I was wrong. The movie was well played out, because of it's cast. The timeline (order of events and linkage of scenes) was perfect. Everything made sense and a few of the scenes were very dramatic. I would definately recommend this movie to anyone. This would be a great family movie to watch because there are no inappropriate love scenes (there was only one scene where there was a kiss on the cheek, but that's really mild.) No bad language that stood out (nothing vulgar is what I mean.) It's a great movie to show to kids because it shows what true family values are, and it shows that no matter what, you can never truely grow up...

I won't write a long review, since several others have done it so well - I just want to encourage anyone who is hesitant to go see 'Finding Neverland.' My best friend and I took along my very reluctant husband, and he ended up enjoying the movie as much as we did. Anyone with a heart, imagination and a dollop of child still within them will be delighted by this movie.  See it!

It's December 2004. Forget the usual spate of tired, formulaic "holiday" pictures (the dreadful "Christmas with the Kranks," for example). Far more appropriate for the season is this sweet fact-based tale of playwright James Barrie (Johnny Depp) and his relationship with an attractive widow, Sylvia Llewelyn-Davies (Kate Winslet), and her sons--a friendship that inspired his classic play "Peter Pan." Foremost among the film's many virtues are the easy and unself-conscious way it slips between fantasy and reality, and its refusal to divide the players into facile heroes and villains. Barrie, played to perfection by Depp, is an enchanting figure to the Llewelyn-Davies boys, but also an impractical dreamer and negligent husband. Nor is all sweetness and light among the family he befriends: Peter (Freddie Highmore), the most sensitive of the boys, and Sylvia's mother Emma (Julie Christie, whose screen appearances these days are infrequent, but always welcome) in particular are wary, at times hostile. The gossip and disapproval that the playwright's unusual relationship with the family aroused are acknowledged as well. The vividness of the characters is due in equal parts to the literate, thoughtful screenplay and the almost uniformly superb quality of the acting. Only Dustin Hoffman seems a bit out of place as Barrie's blustering producer. Even in a winter season rich with films where dialogue and characterization come to the fore ("Sideways," "Closer"), "Finding Neverland" stands out.

Director Marc Forster's "Finding Neverland" is a truly charming, moving, and powerful biographic film of Peter Pan writer J.M. Barrie, played impressively by the great Johnny Depp.  Though "Finding Neverland" does take some liberties in the life of Barrie, for the most part, the film is entirely factual, which makes the tragic story even more affecting.  Balancing tear-jerking sentimentality with moments of childlike (and I mean "childlike" in the bets possible way) delight and warm humor, Forster has created a nearly flawless film that can be enjoyed on many different levels by young and old alike.

My whole family went to see "Finding Neverland" the day before Christmas Eve and we all left the theater teary-eyed yet utterly satisfied with what we all consider to be one of the best films of the year.  Though it never actually mentions the holidays, "Finding Neverland" is the perfect holiday film as it embodies many of the ideas associated with the season: the ability to retain childlike optimism and hope, the notion that people are essentially good if you trust and encourage them, and the faith that a life after death will reunite believers.

Johnny Depp's giddy sense of childlike glee and innocence is so incredibly genuine that it really brings the audience into the world of Barrie. Depp's brilliant performance helps us to understand Barrie's eccentric person by remaining sweet and rueful while suggesting unseen emotional depths.  It is also fascinating to see the reason behind the common theme of many of Barrie's plays; seeking in art a happiness we cannot sustain in life.

Never Say Never is the over-arching theme emerging from the film, Finding Neverland. While Depp is known for doing some of his his best work in twisted tales of insanity, drugs and violence, he is spectacular in his role of James Barrie, creator of Peter Pan.  His ability to think and act like a kid  who never wants to grow up is truly believable in this production.  His performance here will be as remarkable and--never forgotten--as his performance in Pirates of the Carribean.

Because there are grave differences in the characters that he plays in these two movies, Depp should never be described, as only an out of control actor--a director's nightmare as in Pirates of the Carribean. The control that he exhibits in Finding Neverland is ever apparent.  Here, he is astute, reflective, and all-attending to the mother, the children and his film director.

Finding Neverland also has implications for all--children and adults, alike.  Depp's professional growth as an up and coming lead actor signifies that the pursuit of our own personal neverlands should not be limited to some far-off aspect in our lives--some unknown and distant future.  Instead, we should believe in ourselves, and never give up on our dreams, only to discover that finding Neverland is all in how we define it.

Depp's redefinition of himself as a leading actor, father and significant other is bringing about new rewards.  His performance in Finding Neverland is outstanding and overwhelmingly believable.  It is apparent that Depp and James Barrie shared parallel real life experiences--creative wellsprings in a world where everything must fit nicely in a square box.  Because of the shared experience of sometimes being misunderstood as a creative genius, the role is very natural for Depp.  So, natural, that Finding Neverland should achieve Oscar rankings in a variety of areas i.e. acting, directing, filming, costuming etc.

My husband as well as myself enjoyed watching this movie. It is a very touching and well written movie that the whole family can see. My husband was reluctant to see it at first, but after viewing the movie, he had nothing but positive remarks and praises for the movie. We recommend this movie for anyone to see. It will be worth your time and money.

"Finding Neverland" is the story of playwright J.M. Barrie (Depp) attempting to find his muse and create a successful play after a bomb.  He finds that muse in the Davies boys, Peter (highmore), George (Roud), Jack (Prospero), and Michael (Spill), one day in the park when he comes across them and their mother, Sylvia (Winslet) enjoying the day.  They quickly form a close friendship mush to the dismay of Barrie's wife and Sylvia's mother.  While playing make-believe with the kids, ideas start to form in his mind for the story that he will be best known for, "Peter Pan".

This fictional biography is a very entertaining movie to watch.  The director has chosen to incorporate the imagination of the characters into the movie, and as viewers we see the world change back and forth between England and Neverland.  This is used just the right amount, and never becomes distracting.

Depp is his usual excellent self, portraying Barrie as a slightly quirky individual who makes a connection with the Davies family.  The children do decent jobs as the source of his inspiration as well.  The greatest treat for fans of "Peter Pan" will be in how story points take shape, and what outside factors influence the story in progress.  "Finding Neverland" is well worth checking out, although it may be difficult to find as it is currently in limited release.

One wouldn't normally describe a film as being lovely, but it's the first word that comes to mind, well, mine at least, when trying to put together thoughts on Finding Neverland. The second, perhaps, would be sad. That last word, however, is misleading. In the context of this film, sadness is uplifting as it reaffirms one's belief in the power of believing.

For as long as I can remember, the story behind a story/novel/poem/etc. has fascinated me. In the case of Peter Pan, it was the story of how Barrie came to fashion the Lost Boys, and the idea of a child who refused to grow up. I knew from reading a brief biography of Barrie that the loss of his brother at a young age had a severe effect on their mother, which impacted Barrie's own grief. And I was glad to see that that event was mentioned in this film, beautifully illustrating the idea that children should be children while they are able to, and that childhood can disappear, before its time, in the blink of an eye. This film is by no means a faithful biography of Barrie, but then I don't think it was meant to be. There is truth in certain aspects, but there are fabrications as well, which no doubt were intended to heighten the drama of the many relationships involved. As an example, the viewer comes to care a great deal about the unstated, but deeply felt, feelings that Barrie and Sylvia (the mother of the Davies boys) share, which wouldn't have been possible if the makers of the film had followed history and had Sylvia's husband alive as he actually was when the boys met Barrie. The feelings between those two make the ending that much more sad and rather bittersweet. I wouldn't have changed that for the world. Not even for the sake of being more true to life.

The film, in its entirety, is quiet and bright, simple in its expression, but extremely meaningful. It obviously wasn't a lavish production and yet the scenes were rich and the settings nicely detailed. As a viewer, you don't doubt the authenticity of the time it is portraying, which adds overall credibility to the film.

Now, onto the acting. Johnny Depp. Luckily for us, he always has something to offer. A film could be completely unremarkable and yet he manages to make his role unforgettable. Depp personifies the type of actor who slips into the skin of the character he is playing, learning him inside and out, who brings forth all of the mannerisms and quirks that speak of a greater understanding of humanity than most could hope for. But to put it more simply, it comes down to a matter of belief. I, myself, have never doubted him in any role. No matter the time period, or how fantastical his performance may seem, you believe in him. What a wonderful trait for the actor portraying Barrie to have. You believe in him. Kate Winslet, in her role, was wonderful. She exuded an inner happiness and faith and her presence on screen was just glowing. Towards the end of the film when she is viewing the play based on her boys, well, she has never been more beautiful. They couldn't have cast the role better. And as for the boys, each and every one was charming and deserving of recognition for their performances.

Finding Neverland reminds us of the importance of imagination and wonder. And, of course, in believing. Believing in life, believing in things that can't necessarily be seen, but also believing in yourself.

Freddie Highmore (young peter)is a huge blessing to the world through this movie and more to come. A delight to watch! It appears Johnny Depp enjoyed him as well inviting him to appear in the next blockbuster "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" as Charlie himself. This little boy has so much more to give the world. Such a big man in such a little body. Without him this movie would have been less then perfect, and perfect it practically was. Let it take you back to neverland.....And never grow up.

This movie is as touching as they come. It tells the story of J.M. Barrie, the author of Peter Pan, and how his inspiration for it came about. This film takes the audience back in time, to a place they can hardly remember, a Neverland. A place where simply believing in something makes it so.

This film is a truly amazing one, I recommend to everyone, young and old, coward or knight, rich or poor. This film could just be the thing that takes you back to Neverland.

I had originally went to the movies to see "Alexander" but because of it being a late-showing. I went to see "Finding Neverland." This movie was one of the best I have ever seen in my whole life. The movie touched me, made me feel good and made me look at the world in a different way.

The basic storyline was about J.M. Barrie and his life during the writing of Peter Pan. Johnny Depp was astonishing as Barrie. This was really, to me, his defining role. Kate Winslet was also, always as good as Sylvia. One actor that really surprised me was the little boy that played Peter. He has such expressive eyes and is so adorable. The only bad thing, is beyond the boys, Johnny and Kate, the rest of the actors sort of fade into the background.

The visuals were stunning and very whimiscal. It made me want to go to Neverland.

But overall, brilliant film, excellent, there isn't enough words to say how good this is.

Finding Neverland put a perspective of the book, I'd not seen.  I am 66 and STILL wish I could fly like the birds and swim under water without the aid of aparatus.  I still wish there were fairies and mermaids and think this an awesome thought.  Finding Neverland tells me there was once a "kindred spirit".  Mr. Barrie...  I loved the blend of reality and the formation of his famous play, loved witnessing how life bled into his story, loved seeing the impact on the children about whom he wrote.  For me, the film is a must see, again, and again, and I'm already wishing the DVD was released.  For the young and the young at heart, it's a satisfying film.

Johnny does it again and Kate is perfect!  The Victorian Era is captured beautifully and the whole film was a feast for the eyes and imagination from beginning to end.  A wonderful film for the whole family (altho dad might think it a little corny)!

This is my new favorite Johnny Dep movie.  In fact the whole movie was beautifully cast, in my opinion, and it is a fitting tribute to the writer of one of my all-time favorite movies, Peter Pan.

  The story was moving, humorous, and inspiring for all ages.  My 15-year-old grandson immediately wanted to get a leather-bound journal and start jotting down his own ideas for stories; although the 6 year old thought is moved too slowly.

  We saw it twice at the theatre and can hardly wait for it to come out on DVD.

Finding Neverland is undoubtedly the best movie I've seen in the past year.  It may be the best movie I've seen ever.  Despite having been called heartless, I cried for one third of the movie, and walked out of the theater unashamed because it was worth it.  Afterward, I wanted to turn around and watch it again.

A film by Marc Forster

J.M Barrie (Johnny Depp) is something of a failed playwright.  His latest play has just flopped on opening night.  The audience was bored and left the theatre saying how dreadful it was.  His relationship with his wife, Mary (Radha Mitchell) is chilly and loveless.  But James Barrie still has an incredibly fertile imagination, turning the mundane into something more spectacular and wondrous, if only in his mind.  While writing in a park James encounters the Davies family with one of the boys lying under the bench Barrie is sitting on.  This boy is pretending to have been imprisoned by the king, George (Nick Roud), who is really just his older brother.  Barrie, unlike what most adults would do, plays right along with the scene and tries to bargain young Michael (Luke Spill) out of jail.  Immediately Barrie seems to form a friendship with the family, performing a little play with his dog for the family, which includes the mother Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet) and her other two sons Peter (Freddie Highmore) and Jack (Joe Prospero).  Barrie spends more and more time with the Davies, befriending Sylvia and playing make believe with the children.  From this relationship we see instances of Barrie's imagination taking hold and the creation of aspects of "Peter Pan".

Three of the boys join in and play every game with James Barrie, but young Peter does not.  Still grieving and resentful at the death of his father, Peter will not play.  In talking with James, however, Peter starts to come out of his shell.  It is clear that this friendship, which is entirely innocent of anything romantic (in the case of Sylvia) or otherwise is of great comfort both to the Davies family as well as to James Barrie.  There is conflict, of course.  Sylvia's mother, Mrs Emma Du Maurier (Julie Christie) disapproves because of Barrie's behavior but also because she feels that the friendship will only cause a scandal and ruin any chance of Sylvia's being able to remarry into "Society".  Barrie, of course, is married.  This is the other major conflict.  Mary is resentful of the time Barrie spends away from her, but it is also clear that their relationship is not working even before he met Sylvia and her family.  They were already sleeping in separate bedrooms (though that may have been a cultural thing, I am not sure).

While all of this is happening, the producer of Barrie's plays, Charles Frohman (Dustin Hoffman) is trying to get Barrie's new play financed and is very worried when he sees what it is.  It is a play about fairies and children with an alligator and a grown man who must dress up in a dog costume.  Since these plays are shown to the "High Society", it is a play destined to flop.  Coming from the twenty first century, we also know it is destined to become a classic in "Peter Pan".

Rated PG, "Finding Neverland" is a wonderful family film.  In fact, that is the exact word that came to mind as I walked out of the theatre: Wonderful.  There is truly a sense of wonder about J.M. Barrie and his imagination which created Neverland.  His friendship with the Davies comes off as genuine and heartfelt and entirely natural.  Johnny Depp's performance carries the movie, though Winslet and the four children are also to be commended for how well "Finding Neverland" has turned out.  Depp is much more restrained here than in most of his other movie, but he still is able to shine through with a quirkly personality that feels appropriate to Barrie.  "Finding Neverland" is a very imaginative movie, beautifully shot, with enough scenes of Barrie's imagination to override what could have otherwise been a drab London.  This is clearly one of the best movies of the year.

-Joe Sherry

Marc Forster's "Finding Neverland" is a poignant and impeccably crafted testimonial to the power of imagination and how it renews the human spirit in the face of tragedy. I can imagine some people might be disappointed that the film isn't as "magical" as "Peter Pan," the beloved play whose creation it depicts. But Forster isn't creating a fantasy; he is telling a story about real people and the resources of imagination, love and faith they rely on to stay alive. The movie takes some liberties with the story of how James M. Barrie (Johnny Depp) befriends Sylvia Llewellyn Davies (Kate Winslet) and her young sons; for example, Sylvia had five sons, not four, and her husband, Arthur, was still alive when Barrie met the family. But emotionally the film feels right: as Barrie takes Sylvia and the boys on a magical mystery tour of his fecund imagination, the film switches between reality and fantasy with masterful aplomb, and never fails to engage and move its audience. "Finding Neverland" is generous enough to find sympathy even for its less likable characters--Barrie's beautiful but chilly wife Mary (Radha Mitchell) and Sylvia's staid, disapproving mother, Emma du Maurier (Julie Christie). Even though Barrie briefly imagines Emma as Captain Hook, she is not a monster, merely a loving but overly starchy woman with very fixed ideas about what is proper and what isn't. The performances are every bit as excellent as you could wish, and the photography and production design are marvelous. Kelly Macdonald, seen briefly as the actress playing Peter Pan at its premiere, is so good that one hopes she'll get to play the role in earnest before too long. (I must also say a kind word for the actor who plays Nana.)
