I could hear sobs from the audience toward the end of this film, and my guess is that if you don't reach for your handkerchief at least once, you're probably a Captain Hook type yourself. (And if you don't want to go out immediately and buy a Newfoundland after seeing Porthos, the dog that inspired Nana, you just don't like dogs!)

This is the first time I've ever reviewed on Amazon, and had to say this film is one of the most beautiful films I have ever seen.  Johnny Depp is the man for the Oscar handsdown, Kate Winslet best supporting actress handsdown, AND BEST PICTURE for sure!

The story of JM Barrie's life plays out beautifully from beginning to end of how his inspiration of Peter Pan came to be.  The 4 young boys are extraordinary little actors who for sure will have you crying by the end of the film.  The whimsical soundtrack, Victorian Sets and the costuming takes you back to tbe era where going to the Theater was the thing to do! This movie has NO SEX, NO SWEAR WORDS, and really no POLITICS.  Just a nice story for the whole family, especially Barrie fans. To be recommended for sure.

I loved this movie.  When I first saw the title I thought "not another Peter Pan movie, please".  Well it's not just a Peter Pan movie - it's the creation of the Peter Pan story.  Very well written, very well acted.  There are places for laughter and places for tears.  Johnny Depp plays the part of a wonderfully warm, common sensical dreamer.  All four boys are good in their parts, but the one that Peter is fashioned after (besides Johnny Depp) is particularly terrific.  Definitely one I will add to my DVD collection.

I have never cried as many times watching a movie as I did tonight.  I left the movie's feeling almost revived - and thankful.  See this movie, please.  I can truely say that I have a new outlook on life following viewing such a masterpiece.

"Finding Neverland" is a slow, slow, languidly paced film about finding, not only Neverland but what Neverland represents:  the innocence and wonder of childhood before the cold cruel world rears its ugly head.

In itself, this is a good subject for a film but did director Marc Forster (Monster's Ball) have to the set the pace at simmer?

At the center of this film is Johnny Depp's solid performance as James Barrie who wrote the stage play, "Peter Pan" and who "adopts" a widow (a radiant Kate Winslett) and her four boys as a way of filling in his own lonely life with the exuberance of children and childhood and as a way of making up for a loveless marriage.

Depp never fails to do good work and he does so here once again. But it is all so deadly serious that whenever the two crumudgeons of this piece, Dustin Hoffman (Charles Frohman) and Julie Christie (Emma du Maurier) come onscreen they inject some much needed life into the proceedings with their wit and nasty dispositions.

"Finding Neverland" never takes flight, as it should, being that it is based on the life of the man who invented Peter Pan but nonetheless it is a solid film, cast with solid actors, directed solidly by Forster. Unfortunately, it is also solidly clear that with all this talent involved: something, someone took the wrong turn and ended up, not in Neverland, but in Dullsville.

One reviewer here suggests that you should not seek out the "true" story of how Peter Pan came to be made, because if you do, and then compare the true story to this movie, your enjoyment of Finding Neverland will decrease significantly. I must respectfully disagree with that. Yes, there were a few facts that were fudged - but that's all, just a few. The core of both stories is the same: how an adult came to find a muse within children, and to use his inspiration to write a genre breaking play that gave the world one of the most endearing characters in all of fiction.

Unlike many who have posted reviews, I have never been overly fond of Johnny Depp. However, that was not the case in this film. I've seen countless films of his, and enjoyed them on one level or another, but his personal involvement never affected me in a positive way. The perfect example for this is Chocolat, easily one of my favorite films, but I could have taken or left Johnny Depp. Finding Neverland has changed my opinion of Mr. Depp entirely, and I now count myself one of his fans. His performance was so understated, so sublime, so perfect that he made an admirer out of me. It takes an amazing performance to do such a thing, and this was an amazing performance.

Kate Winslet was Kate Winslet: without fault, capable of evoking emotion with a simple cough. The moment she appeared on the screen seemed almost to be the beginning of the film. Rather - the moment her character and her character's children appeared on film was when it really began

Winslet and Depp had terrific chemistry on screen - in fact, they may have had too much. They looked so good when they were together, that it seemed as if they should have been husband and wife. I kept expecting them to get together, but since one of the fudged facts is that Winslet's character's husband was still alive during all of this, that was impossible.

The film did a wonderful job showing something that would have been highly frowned upon in today's society. A grown man, spending all of his time with children? There may have been a restraining order placed upon him with today's sensibilities. Thankfully, yesterday wasn't today.

I saw Finding Neverland last weekend and I have to say I have never seen Johnny Depp put on a finer performance.  I was absolutely captivated and the little boy who played Peter won my heart.  Excellant film and one that I will have to own.

Peter Pan soars; Finding Neverland kind of hops along, sometimes airborne, sometimes very earthbound.  The highlight is certainly the last 20 minutes or so, with the opening night performance of Barrie's play and then the private staging of it at the Davies home.  Much of the rest of the elegantly staged and acted film feels exactly that way -- a collection of set pieces laid end to end for a couple hours.  Peter Pan is all about play, energy and imagination but even when playing Johnny Depp and the Davies boys seem more like they are working than having fun.  (What looks like the most fun, in fact, is the game the boys are playing when young Michael is found beneath Barrie's park bench.)  Depp is more burdened and tired than mischievous and flighty in his interpretation of Barrie -- and that may be exactly right, but again, it's not exactly fun.  In Barrie's increasingly loveless marriage, all this viewer's sympathies lie with his wife.  His neglect of her is shameless and selfish, as is his reaction when -- after being away from home night after night with the Davies -- he comes home to find that she once, once!, has chatted late into the night with a male visitor who came looking for Barrie.  And Kate Winslet has little to do but look, first, overwhelmed by four active boys and then consumptive -- which she does quite fetchingly.  My question is whether there has ever been a more "she's a goner" movie cough than the one Winslet produces as she and Depp are walking to watch a play her sons have staged.  Dustin Hoffman, on the other hand, has a wonderful time playing the role of Barrie's long-suffering producer.  And it's too bad we can't all age as well as Julie Christie, who also has a great time with her disciplinarian Grandma part.

Historically very inaccurate, Finding Neverland is entertaining and worth seeing, but not the monument of cinema it sets itself to be.

Spectacular, very entertaining, magical. Completely takes you away from anything you've ever seen before and enters a world you never believed existed. Depp and Winslet bring the screen alive with things you never thought possible. Absolutely wonderful, fun and moving. It's a must see!

Johnny Depp has never been an actor to do "mainstream" movies, with the exception of Pirates of the Caribbean.  The same holds true for Finding Neverland, which has a feel of an independent movie.

The story takes place in 1903 and is about author J.M. Barrie (Depp) and how he became inspired to write the play "Peter Pan."  Basically he was at the park and met the Davies Family.  Sylvia (Kate Winslet) is the mom/widow of the family whom has four boys that she is responsible for.  James begins the hang out with the family on a regular basis.  He plays cowboys or pirates with the boys.  As he does this, he writes down all of his ideas and images, which eventually turns out to be "Peter Pan."

Johnny Depp gaves an amazing performance.  I really hope that he gets his long over-due Oscar for this performance.  Everytime that he is in a movie, he makes it a better.  He is the perfect person to play the role of a grown man who doesn't want to grow up.  Kate Winslet also gives a good, dramatic performance.  Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman are also featured in this film and due well for having limited roles.

The movies itself was really good.  It seems like the kind of movie that would get boring, but it actually didn't.  I was very interested in the movie the whole way through.  Marc Forster did an excellent job of directing this movie.  I especially like how he showed what James is thinking in his imagination.  Also the way the recreation of the original "Peter Pan" play is something to see.  Forster definately did his homework on the original "Peter Pan" play.

So my recommendation is the check this movie out.  It is a very entertaining movie, that provides you with a good message.  Imagination is the greatest gift of all and to always try to find and keep alive the inner child in you.  Thats a great message, but just don't take it to Michael Jackson levels.

LOVED IT!!!!  Johnny Depp & Kate Winslet were perfect together!!!  Fun for the whole family!!!  Look for the boy who plays Peter in Tim Burton's Willy Wonka & the Choclate Factory.  Johnny Depp will be playing Mr. Wonka.

FINDING NEVERLAND is that rare work of art that transcends the medium of film and becomes a spirit-altering experience.  Strong accolades?  Gush?  Perhaps so, but squeeze time out of the clutter of life and the holidays to see this movie and be transported to a place that nurturingly reassures us that the cycle of life is indeed good.  Find Neverland!

Marc Forster ('Monster Ball') has created a lovingly tender look at the playwright JM Barrie (Johnny Depp) in 1903 when, down on his luck with theater flops, unfulfilled by a marriage of Victorian standards to a beautiful but aloof and social climbing wife Mary (Radha Mitchell), and with writer's block, he encounters the Llewellyn Davies family - a widow Sylvia (Kate Winslet) and her four boys, George (Nick Roud), Jack (Joe Prospero), Michael (Luke Spill) and Peter (Freddie Highmore) - playing blissfully in Kensington Gardens.  Barrie is captivated, draws the boys to him with his patient and infectious enthusiasm for play, and bonds with this family, gaining the obvious seeds for his highest achievement or creation, PETER PAN.

How these seeds grow, despite the soft, yet supportive, growling of his producer Charles Frohman (Dustin Hoffman) and the not so soft interference of Sylvia's wealthy haughty mother Madame du Maurier (Julie Christie), form the storyline of this film.  The magic comes from the skill of the writers (Alan Knee and David Magee) and director, the cinematographer (never has Victorian London glowed with such elegant gaslight presence), and the musical score by Jan Kaczmarek.  Cameo roles are treated with tremendous respect: Eileen Essel as Mrs. Snow, Ian Hart as Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Kelly MacDonald as the first Peter Pan, etc all are brief but fully realized and poignant.

Given this support it is obvious that the talents of the lead performers will shine, and they glow they do with such understated performances that make the simple story of the sanctity of the inner child so cogent that there is not a dry eye in the house during the thankfully long credits.  Johnny Depp continues to prove that he is one of the finest actors on the screen today: his Barrie has a flawless Scottish accent and a manner of movement and facial expressions that make him a gentle hero.  Kate Winslet, never more beautiful, likewise embodies Sylvia with exactly the right amount of perk and pathos, and as her mother, Julie Christie is strikingly beautiful and unfailingly solid in a role less than loving.  The boys are artfully recreated, never absurdly over the top, always very close to the bridge that crosses the craggy canyon between childhood and adulthood.  Growing up has never been better portrayed -  by all of the characters!

In a time when too often films that address magic and imagination rely on computer effects to create creatures that are comic book absurd, FINDING NEVERLAND relies on simply showing the stage mechanics of the play, suspending wires and all, even in the climax of the story when Barrie brings his successful play to the living room of the ill Sylvia in order to keep his promise to her to take her to Neverland.  No gimmicks here, just solid stagecraft very much in keeping with the inherent magic of Barrie's enduring play.  This is a brilliant cinematic accomplishment - a feast for the eyes, the ears, the brain, and the soul.  Please don't miss it!  Grady Harp, November 2004

This is the bittersweet story of J.M. Barrie's inspiration for his classic play "Peter Pan".  Casting for this movie is exceptional, and the performances by Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet are both profound and exceptionally human.  The young actors portraying the Llewelyn-Davies boys are extraodinarily fine young actors, and totally believable in their characterizations.  Julie Christie as Sylvia's mother, and Dustin Hoffman as J.M. Barrie's producer round out this excellent performance.  Poignant moment:  when J.M. Barrie inquires after Mr. Snow, and is told my Mrs. Snow that he has passed away.  Her comment to J.M. Barrie sums up how life should be lived.

I was eager to see "Finding Neverland" but I knew that the film had a couple of high hurdles to overcome.  The first is that I loved last year's version of "Peter Pan" from director P.J. Hogan, who crafted what I think will be the best version of the beloved story for adults.  Certainly no other version of "Peter Pan" has touched upon the depths of the tale of the boy who never grew up.  The second is that I also have fond memories of the television movie "The Dreamer of Oz," which told the story of L. Frank Baum (played by John Ritter) and how he crafted the characters and story of "The Wizard of Oz."  "Finding Neverland" is in a similar vein, more comparable to "Dreamchild" (about "Alice in Wonderland") although it is more interested in the magic that was created on stage when the play first premiered than in detailing the specific sources of inspiration.

"Finding Neverland" is about how J. M. Barrie (Johnny Depp) came to write one of the classic children's stories of all time (you start counting them on one hand and "Peter Pan" has to be there).  The situation as set up in the film is that Barrie's latest play has been a flop and his financier, Charles Frohman (Dustin Hoffman) needs another play to keep the theater and the cast afloat.  So Barrie heads off to the park with his journal and his dog to seek inspiration, which is revealed to him through a strategic hole in his newspaper and by the presence of a small boy imprisoned in a dungeon beneath his park bench.

So it is that Barrie is introduced to the family of Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslet), a widow with four sons: George (Nick Roud), Jack (Joe Propsero), Michael (Luke Spill), and Peter (Freddie Highmore).  Slyvia and her children become not only a source of inspiration for the Lost Boys, Pirates, and Indians of Neverland but the family he never had.  But even in this reimagined version of how "Peter Pan" came to be written it is clear that Barrie does not want to be a father.  He wants to be a brother, and eventually we find out why that would be an important gap in his life to be filled.

Mary Answell Barrie (Radha Mitchell) is not happy that her husband is seeking inspiration with another woman and her family, and Barrie seems to be on cusp of scandal as he continues to do what he want and writes his new play.  Mary is not a sympathetic figure because it is clear from the start that she has no idea what sort of man she is married to (we can debate exactly what that means, but whatever the interpretation the point is valid).  She thinks that her husband is cheating on her, and one of the ironies of the film is he does not do so, by either the conventional meaning of the term or the privileged meaning it has for her, until after his wife has beaten him to the punch.  Slyvia's mother, Mrs. Emma du Maurier (Julie Christie) disapproves of the relationship between "Uncle Jimmy" and her grandchildren and what it means for the prospects of her daughter remarrying.

Ultimately "Finding Neverland" is about the relationships Barrie had with Sylvia and Peter, more than it is about the creation of the play "Peter Pan."  But it is when we get to the final act of this film, adapted by David Magee form Allan Knee's play, that director Marc Forster's movie becomes truly magical.  Barrie knows that he has created a work of genius, approaching this opening night with a supreme confidence he lacked for his work at the start of the film, having assured success by reserving 25 seats in the theater for his play's perfect audience.  But opening night is only the first half of the magic, and the second act brings together the major elements of the story into a sublime moment of beauty and wonder.

I was disappointed that there was not more of Barrie's actual play, but then I realized that was because I erroneously thought that in the case of "Finding Neverland" the play is the thing.  What sets up the endings of this film is not the play, but the relationships that have been built while we distracting look for the first signs of Captain Hook and Tinkerbelle.  This is a movie where the climax is everything you hoped it would be and redeems whatever shortcomings you see in the film up to that point, even if it is only in retrospect that you understand how it was set up.

Depp's performance is incredibly understated by his standards, and I would imagine that an Oscar nomination and perhaps even winning the award could result from this film because of the immense respect and affection he has garnered in recent years with his stellar body of work.  But he is merely a conduit for something larger in this case, and if he is the recipient of the universal reservoir of good will engendered by a story that is about to celebrate its centennial, I have no problem with that.  Winslet continues to create a solid body of work without most people noticing, and while much will be made of Highmore's Peter it is Roud as George, the oldest son who if forced to be an adult in the span of thirty seconds by the circumstances of his life who captures my attention in a film celebrating the boy who never grew up and the man who wrote his story.

WARNING: If you find yourself bespelled by "Finding Neverland" and want to find out how much of the story is true when you get online, all I can say in the strongest possible terms is DO NOT do that.  It will ruin your memories of this movie forever.  I am not even close to joking on this one and you have all been duly warned.

'Finding Neverland' is a fictionalized account of play-write J.M. Barrie's inspirations that would result in possibly his most famous work, 'Peter Pan.'  This inspiration is the Llewelyn Davies family, composed of the widowed Sylvia (Kate Winslet), her cynical mother (Julie Christie), and her four boys, including the "young adult" Peter (Freddie Highmore), increasingly apathetic and depressed following his father's death.  The story is one of magic, as is the film.  However, despite the opportunity for more interesting subject matter, director Mark Forster's new film feels quite processed; one can tell the cheese-loving Miramax produces.  There are no difficulties, nothing challenges the audience; even the performances given by an appropriately softened Depp and the disappointingly plain (it's not like she was given much to work with) Kate Winslet seem to settle at one horizon and cease to expand upon their respective characters or develop nuance.  But despite its short-comings, 'Finding Neverland' is an often-times endearing piece of work, proving perfect in production value; there are even delicious supporting roles that seem to exist only to spice up the screen with the likes of Julie Christie and Dustin Hoffman, both doing well with small, underwritten roles.  The highlight of the film, though, is young Freddie Highmore, who, despite his young age, manages to fully emote and elicit honest emotional response (in a key break-down scene, Highmore nearly had me in tears).  He, among other reasons, will draw many to the film (I expect 'Neverland' to rank high on weekend box office charts).  Mark Forster sets the film at a generously even pace, so 'Neverland' will keep its audience awake.  But the screenplay falls short of making its themes of imagination vs. cynicism entirely convincing, as there is lack of character development throughout, and many adults herein feel much too black-and-white during a rather quick group transition from stern to jovial.  Though I recommend 'Neverland' to some, I am still a bit reserved as many may be disappointed in its lack of intense feel-good moments and "inspirational" schmaltz.  Unlike the play 'Peter Pan' itself, Forster's own Neverland is too simple and restricted to be entirely moving.

OK, so I may be a fan of both Johnny Depp & Kate Winslett but I'm not always a fan of their films.  Still, one doesn't have to be a fan to like, or even love, this movie -- it stands on its own magical merits.  Perhaps Tinkerbell scattered some fairy dust on Finding Neverland because it's absolutely one of the best films of 2004 and it should certainly give Depp another Oscar nom, and maybe garner a few more for Best Film, Director, Costumes, Art Direction and Set Design as well.  The movie's blend of the real world (the England of J.M Barrie) and the scenes of magical imagination are flawlessly intertwined and filled with both the innocent delight of children and the bittersweet realities of adults.  The performances are uniformly terrific: Kate Winslett shines and Johnny Depp delivers a superbly shaded, low-key performance with a great Scottish accent (although I'm certainly no expert).  Not really a children's film although older ones may enjoy it and adults can't help but be enchanted.  If only more films like this could be made to balance out the numerous overly-loud, explosive, high-concept/low-brained films that flood the multiplexes...but there probably isn't enough fairy dust in the universe to make that happen.  Fly to Finding Neverland and give yourself an early holiday treat.

I recommend you to watch finding neverland, because the story is excellent, historic and interesting and it's also a true story.

It's never boring.

The actors are great. I think that the movie should receive an oscar!

You will not be disappointed.

This story is based on James Barrie, the playwright best known for Peter Pan and it is one of the best films that I've seen this year, despite receiving next to no hype or marketing push.

James Barrie (Johnny Depp) is a playwright, successful enough to have a nice house with servants, and a beautiful wife (Radha Mitchell). Still, his marriage seems distant and he is bothered by the mediocrity of his creative output. On opening night, people complement him on his terrible plays and he knows they are just trying to be nice.

One day while sitting on a park bench, he encounters three adolescent boys, who he quickly befriends. He invites them over for dinner and also solidifies a friendship with their mother, played by Kate Winslet, much to the disappointment of his wife and her mother, the stern, protective Julie Christie. The boy's father died from cancer and to some extent, his becomes their playmate, without trying to replace their dad. At the same time, his wife becomes increasingly disenchanted that her husband is spending so much time with another woman and her children.

As his friendship grows with the boys and her mother, he begins to develop a play, loosely based about them. While initially met with skepticism in the planning stages, the play ends up becoming Barrie's most famous creation.

While less visually fantastic than last year's Big Fish by Tim Burton, Finding Neverland has its own tastefully limited special effects, but it outshines Burton's film in its amount of sheer heart.

I actually ended up seeing this film since I arrived too late for the film I originally wanted to see. At the end of Finding Neverland, I was not even slightly surprised to see the audience burst into applause. It was also nice to see that the film was sold out.

The acting is well done without being spectacular. I enjoyed Johnny Depp's performance, but he didn't play the role with an extraordinary amount of charisma. Some people will see this as a failing, but I think a genuine performance is better than glitzy but shallow one. One of the children is particularly strong, playing the role of Peter. He's the youngest but at the same time he's complex, cynical and surprisingly mature.

I saw this film at a sneak preview last Thursday night, and was utterly enthralled with it from start to finish. Johnny Depp shines in one of the best performances of his career as J.M. Barrie, a Scottish playwright, who after coming off of his last poorly reviewed play, struggles for inspiration. And this he finds, in the minds and hearts of the Lywellyn-Davies family, a widowed Sylvia Lywellyn-Davies, and her four young boys, whom he meets by chance in a nearby park. The children are immediately enthralled by Barrie's childlike manner and his wild imagination, (Barrie equally so) and he soon becomes a prominent figure in their lives, and the life of Sylvia, much to the gossip of the town, and the dismay of Barrie's wife, Mary. From his relationship with this family, Barrie soon begins to write the play that would remain a classic forever, "Peter Pan".

One of the things I liked best about this film are the performances, which are incredible. Johnny Depp, who has been named an Oscar contender for Best Actor, is perfect in the role of the quirky and imaginative Barrie. As Sylvia, Kate Winslet is astounding, and the supporting cast of Dustin Hoffman, Julie Christie, and Radha Mitchell are a pleasure to watch. However, the performance that truly blew me away in "Finding Neverland" was that of Freddie Highmore. At the mere age of twelve, he seems to embody innocence, and is captivating and moving as Sylvia's youngest son, Peter. Keep an eye on this young man, he can next be seen in another beloved tale, "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" as Charlie Bucket.

The world of J.M. Barrie was rich in color, life, and imagination, and the filmmakers in "Finding Neverland" have done a brilliant job of bringing that world to life. This film manages to make the audience laugh and cry, and truly feel for the characters onscreen, which is something that is not achieved often. I would truly recommend "Finding Neverland" for anyone wanting a terrific story, wonderful performances, and, of course, a little magic to brighten an evening.

I saw Finding Neverland last week in a special "sneak preview." I found it amazing, and was in tears at the end.

Johnny Depp is amazingly gorgeous, versatile, and is a perfect JM Barrie. Kate Winslet gives a delicate, heartwarming performance as a mother with a disease. Dustin Hoffman brought me to stitches at many times during the film with his funny deadpan lines. You will also see a familiar face from "Pirates of the Caribbean," one of the funniest soldiers in the film is now "Nana" in "Finding Neverland." Freddie Highmore, a young child actor gives an astonishing tearful performance as an angered child, yearning for his father.

The film, with a fantastic cast, brought me to tears and laughter, and left me feeling inspired and happy at the end.

I saw Finding Neverland tonight in a sneak preview. I wish I had words for it. Everything from the imagery to the acting to the overall everlasting, practical idealism just leaves you with a feeling of having a bird trapped in your chest, which can only be released by either laughing or crying. Everyone could use a dose of imagination in their life, even if it's just imagining the person standing next to you at the bus stop breaking out into a tap dance.

I highly recommend this movie; as soon as it comes out nationwide, I'll be seeing it again. And as soon as it's on DVD, I'll be first in line to buy it. :-)

I went to the screening of `Finding Neverland' and found it to be a wonderful movie! Rarely do we get to watch a movie in which the story is filled with so much fantasy, imagination, and spirit that will keep us entertained throughout the movie.

The story starts off with James Barrie, a Scottish playwright whose most recent work is a failure. One day in the park, he meets Sylvia Davies, a widow, and her four boys and strikes up a conversation with him. Little by little, he becomes closer to them, and gets inspired to write a new play, one that would be one of the greatest classics of our time.

The film focuses mainly on Barrie's relationship with the Davies family, and by viewing small things such as the children's behavior, how he created Peter Pan and the Lost Boys, and added the pirates and the Indians to create a magical masterpiece.

Marc Forster, the director of this movie (who also directed Monster's Ball) gives us magic in this story inspired by the life of James Barrie, the author of `Peter Pan'. Johnny Depp acted flawlessly as J.M.Barrie. His expressions (along with the accent) were perfect, and his performance laudable. The rest of the cast, including Kate Winslet, Dustin Hoffman and Julie Christie also acted incredibly well. However, I was really amazed by the performance of Freddie Highmore, the young boy who acted as Peter Davies in the movie, especially towards the end of the movie.

I think this is one of the best movies to be released this year. If you loved watching movies like `Big Fish', you will definitely enjoy this movie.

The role of unpredictable writer J.M. Barrie is one that Johnny Depp was born to play. Only an actor who blends eccentricity and sensitivity as seamlessly as Depp could ever think of inhabiting an artist who created a literary world of pirates, fairies and pixie dust to combat the social pressures and personal tragedies that torment humanity. As I watched Depp morph into the 19th century British aristocrat that crafted the unforgettable adventures of Peter Pan, I was stunned to find that many of the nuances and emotions that had characterized his most memorable performances were coalescing before my eyes: I saw the abiding sweetness of Edward Scissorhands mingling with the unbridled optimism and energy of Ed Wood and the sheer lust for life that inhabited Captain Jack Sparrow. The result is a performance that is as dynamic, affecting and disarmingly enjoyable as any I've seen this year, and one that defines the persona and uniqueness of Johnny Depp just as clearly as the part of Rhett Butler revealed all the priorities and charm of Clark Gable. Even without such a brilliant star turn, Finding Neverland would still be an extremely pleasant and moving parable about the use of creativity and imagination to confront personal demons, but Depp elevates the film into the realm of magic.

When the movie commences, Barrie's life is in dismal condition. His latest play is an unqualified disaster, his producer Charles Frohman (a very amusing Dustin Hoffman) has little faith in his future prospects as a writer, and he is trapped in a confining marriage to a humorless social climber (Radha Mitchell). Things take a turn for the better when he encounters the Davies family, a harried brood that consists of four boys and widowed mother Sylvia (Kate Winslet). Their lives have been dispirited since the death of the patriarch, and they will come to know more suffering when Sylvia begins showing the symptoms of consumption. Barrie revives the passion and purpose in his own life by teaching the Davies boys to mitigate their grief through whimsy and imagination, and the innocence and playfulness of the children ultimately inspires the timeless story of Peter Pan.

In several marvelously inventive and well-constructed sequences, director Marc Forster cuts between the elaborate fantasy worlds imagined by Barrie and the children and the prosaic backyard circumstances they are escaping. Depp transforms himself into pirate captains, Indian chiefs and circus performers with incredible style and panache, and his sheer giddiness is always infectious among the audience. Such outlandishness is always thrilling to watch, but Depp is equally effective in quieter and more reflective moments. He conveys an appropriate mix of frustration and pity in his conversations with his chilly wife, and the scene in which he confides to Sylvia the tragic family history that led him to pursue a career as an imagineer is a masterpiece of restrained, heartfelt acting.

Forster is to be congratulated for finding such brilliant child actors to play off of Depp's franticness and compassion. Freddie Highmore is unforgettable in the role of Peter, the pragmatic middle child who resists Barrie's games and adventures because they blind him to the important and tragic events occurring in his life. Highmore traces Peter's emotional journey with maturity and depth, best epitomized by his changing attitudes toward creative writing. Equally excellent is Nick Roud as eldest son George, who requires Barrie's help to balance the burgeoning responsibilities and maturity that come with adolescence and his own desire for fantasy and frivolity. And Luke Spill (playing the role of youngest child Michael Davies) is quite simply the most adorable moppet to grace the screen since Drew Barrymore in E.T. I defy any audience member not to lose their heart to him within thirty seconds of his arrival on screen.

Finding Neverland may focus most of its attention on the male bonding between Barrie and the Davies boys, but the women do not get lost in the shuffle. Although Mrs. Davies seems to exist initially as a romantic alternative to Mrs. Barrie, Sylvia movingly emerges as the greatest convert to Barrie's glorious world of make-believe. As her health deteriorates, she relies on magic and fantasy to bring her hope and hold her family together. Winslet plays the role with an astonishing mix of resoluteness and vulnerability, and she will probably be joining Depp as one of this year's most prominent Oscar contenders. Veteran actress Julie Christie also deserves a great deal of credit for humanizing the essentially villainous character of Mrs. Du Maurier, Sylvia's rigid mother. Her eyes and body language always capture the essence of a woman who wishes to protect her daughter at any cost, even when her dialogue characterizes her as a one-note harpy bent on driving Barrie's imaginative nonsense from the family household.

Despite reports from the Barrie estate that Finding Neverland distorts many of the events in the writer's life, the film is always true to his spirited personality and literary priorities. Barrie was an illusionist who would have welcomed any creative touches that might have rendered his life story more exciting, uproarious or touching, if only to inspire and enchant the audience. He would have adored this thought-provoking gem of a movie and treasured Depp's bravura performance, just as audiences will today.

The only reason I did not give this movie a ONE STAR is because the production values and acting were excellent.  But this movie is a whitewash of JM Barrie's true creepiness.  It does not mention that he altered Sylvia's will to make himself guardian of the boys, the strange circumstances of her death and his long sinister relationship with the entire family or that two of the boys committed suicide.  Barrie was not a person you would want around after your own children.

This movie had some creepy undertones which didn't make sense. After watching it I read that the real J.M. Barrie was most certainly a sick pedophile who did infact destroy the family whose boys he preyed on. The truth behind Barrie is so sick and a suicide theme was an unusual ending in the original play featured in this cheerful movie. A theme which, it turns out, played out in real life anong one of the children he preyed on. Hollywood is early such a sick world, only harvey Weinsteins would choose to gloss up a story as dark as this one. This has sort of ruined Peter Pan for me.
